Title: Rewrote my review after the 4th watch of Joker - I've liked jokers before, but this is the 1st time I truly loved... a Joker! Here is why:
Review: Someone said to me that Arthur Fleck chooses to burn the world he's not adapted to, and I answered her: it wasn't a choice. It was an escape, his only true option towards earning some satisfaction, opposed to endless misery he was constantly living in. Arthur never had any joy, or at least some degree of vindication of any kind in "the normal world", as this normal world battered and beleaguered him at every turn, putting him down repeatedly as that would be his place. Did he lash out? No, he got up like a good boy, over and over again, dozens of times just to be thrown down again. Until one day, he fought back, surprising himself he could do it! And what do you know? It worked! Shocked by the outcome, he tried again the worlds way, the kind and tolerant way, and the world has again made fun of him, and thus leaving him with the only option that makes him feel something besides it, the only option that works: to fight back, realizing that ultimately the only way you could have some satisfaction in this up world if you are Arthur Fleck, is to rebel against it! And that's funny, especially when you've been such a good boy, trying to do good by everyone! This is the true final paradox, the realization that the answer hit you in the face and you didn't see it all along, and this fact makes him think his life is an actual comedy rather than a tragedy. As I said in my few words of my previous review, the only way The Joker could be the hero is if he would somehow be able to make everyone else seem like the villains! And for the very 1st time, in this majestic masterpiece called Joker, he vilifies the whole society, and from a certain point of view arising the need for it to burn!Of course his life is one of tragedy, one of the cruelest imaginable. The very distance between perpetual humiliation and the choice to fight back being so tiny, but in the same time his inability to see it for so long is what constitutes the final paradox, almost making it sound like a comedy. Throughout the movie he cries while laughing or laughs while crying, but that's not the initial paradox. The initial paradox (reason) is easily spotted by anyone with deep enough empathy: when our human nature isn't able to handle the troubles anymore, pain seems unstoppable and the overflow of negative emotions is handled in opposing fashion. When the more you try, the worse it gets, you have 2 options: either you give up completely and kill yourself or although it hurts, you just laugh it out, you spit fate right in it's face! Arthur has lived this particular emotional paradox way before the action in the movie begins, because living it so many times before, by the time the movie starts the paradox is already part of his conscience, it's already a pathology, that's why when he's feeling unexpectedly sad or edgy, he's sent back in his mind to the paradox, to the uncontrolled laughter. That being the former reason for his behavior, the later being his whole life was a lie, from his detrimental mother to his submissive behavior; once cured from both, he could free himself from the decades of suffering also. The final paradox being the inconceivable: the fight against society bringing him vindication, instead of obvious defeat! Here is where our Joker differs from all of the villains of literature or classical culture, you can't pick a fight with society and win! Well, as it turns out... you can, if you're Joaquin Phoenix! Even his name is somewhat predestined for this, he was a good actor with an accomplished career but nobody had the nerve to call him genius before. And when everyone has forgotten about him, expecting him to die and be buried as an actor that will never know greatness, he arises and slams the door over your face with this Joker! And now, nobody can call him less than a genius, not even those who's brains aren't skilled enough to appreciate the movie.So this is the initial paradox described in detail: you try to do right by your workplace - you're rewarded with laughter and abuse, you try to do a good thing in a buss - you're rewarded with insult and affront, you take good care of your mother, you go to (the super fun) work to provide for her, you wash her, you cook for her, you speak nice to her and listen to her - you find out she abused you when you were a boy without even knowing, that she's crazy, and the ultimate buffer reward of all: she's not even your mother! Notwithstanding the fact you're having a romance with the attractive colored neighbor that lives down the hall, that supposedly can carry you through the rough times, just to be again rewarded with the stupefyingly truth: SUPRISE, IT'S ALL IN YOUR HEAD! (I lost it there.) There's no way that you wouldn't ultimately laugh at the merit that's completely at odds with the reward given, without fu.king exception! It's way over the stage of complete sadness, it's complete madness, it doesn't make sense, and what do you do when something intense felt doesn't make sense? You laugh. You go back and forth between tragedy and comedy like it's a roller coaster, a confusion trip from which there's no escape! It's no rational confusion, there's nothing wrong with Arthur's reason, it's an emotional confusion, 2 opposite feelings experienced in the same time! If we accept as common practice that we can cry out of sadness, sometimes even out of joy, Arthur teaches us that under extraordinary duress, prolonged indefinitely, one can laugh out of sadness. Moreover so, you can develop a pathology in this regard. What he feels in the moment he realizes everything is a lie is the most choking emotion possible, when you're at your utmost end of your mental supplies, fallen past the edge. I have never quite seen that so well described as in this movie! Arthur's reason is never impaired, no matter how strong negative emotions, they never quite conquer his reason but flow in sink with it, as such, the radical difference between those who kill themselves and him is that he realizes that he still has value, even if nobody notices it, not even his own mother "Aren't you supposed to be funny, to be a comedian?". But real or not, he believes "People are starting to notice!", even though he is contradicted by the gross reality of his failed stand up comedy. Oddly enough, he's not completely wrong as that sentence starts becoming reality just after he's left without anything more to lose, and forced to act as much as he can in his own defence, as nobody else does! Masterpiece. Need I say more? No problem.Just because he's left better off at the end of this movie than at it's beginning, doesn't mean we're gonna see a happy Joker in Joker 2! Not by a long shot, but strictly comparing him with his Joker one torment, I think he will be considerably better. I am surprised the creator of this movie, being one and the same, has actually decided to make a sequel! No matter how much money you receive from the producer company, to my mind, I can't possibly imagine how you could write a continuation, without tarnishing Arthur's personality shown in Joker 1. You can't turn him directly 150 degrees (considering 30 degrees he's already turned at the end of the 1st movie), a proper solid turn must be made, time and character consuming, because as we should know by now, Arthur cares a lot about "nobody's people" that have decency and compassion, even if he doesn't realize it, like he was until just recently, like the dwarf guy is and Arthur kissed him fatherly over his baldness showing his emotions of appreciation "You're the only one who's ever been kind to me!", making it blatantly obvious he does not ignore kindness in people. As opposite to what he shots his gun at! Occasionally dips his scissors in. (I like that Jackie Chan moment there, you can use any household item as a weapon - Kung Fu, right?) Joking aside, Arthur's morals are strong and the most obvious when he shouts his heart out on Gotham television "Nobody thinks how it's to be the other guy!", motto that in my opinion is the very center of his character! But that doesn't fit one bit with the classic Joker of the comic books or Nolan's Joker from The Dark Knight, it's a totally new approach of a Joker! That's why I love him. And those who think that motto is a joke, deserve more than just a bullet through their infectious thoughts, they would get off too easy! Because they are left way behind on the chapter of emotional inferno and need to be compensated accordingly, in order to understand what's it like! One of them being the rich mayor to be as he calls all of those trapped in this inferno as "Nothing but clowns!". But he gets what's coming to him, although a bit more pain wouldn't have hurt rather than complete oblivion that doesn't do him any good, aside from rising later on The Dark Knight. Back to Arthur and his live performance, nobody would have even cared what he shouted on that podium with all his might, if he wouldn't have made a clear point at the end, pointing out who's mean, why and what's coming to them mean ones, exemplified plenty and without any doubt! If he wouldn't have, they would have just thrown him out in the street like a piece of garbage and his words with him.I want to say that another impressive feature is that this movie despite it's visceral drama also has cool comedy in it, some obvious, some noticed at later viewing and exemplify them but I'm running out of character space(..) In conclusion, in my 1st review I said that the scenery is just good enough, but after seeing the movie 4 times I realized just how brilliant it is! Combined with one of the best performances of an actor in the history of cinematography and a sound theme that make your eyes fall off right between your tears, it can't be denied as one of humanity's all time masterpieces. When or if alien races will ever contact us, there's ample reason we are a worthy race, just like Arthur and this movie is my proof towards our humanity's worth.

Title: Am I a joker sympathiser? Yes.
Review: This is a standalone film for The Joker, to understand his character and really identify with his personality! welcome to the beginning of the end! The film compells you to believe the joker can justify his crimes! That one man does have the power to take down those who abuse their so called " higher social status"A man whose childhood has been subjected to acts of Evil, and has continued to suffer more subtly throughout his adult life, we as the audience must believe he is out to force that evil upon the world! So that they too, know for a moment, what's it's like to be the victim! This is his reasoning! A coming of age depicts a character created out of pure Evil. A society which has failed to recognise and listen, a society where everything is seen as a product. A society which divides people and forces entertainment to be at the heart of people's lives, sacrificing the expense of another's misery along the way. Anyone with a heart will feel empathy and understanding towards the Joker.Batman is one of my favourite characters, becuase his abilities are not overly far-fetched, and the sense of what could be real is far more believable than having the ability to fly! But truthfully their would be NO BATMAN without the joker.And here you have Joaquin Phoenix portraying the joker in a light never seen before! His performance is remarkable, diverse, captivating and emotional!Honestly, this is the best acting performance I have ever seen, regardless of genre, since solo performances from the likes of Kevin Spacey.I am grateful to be one of the first to have witnessed such a powerful performance in the cinema on it's initial release date! And will continue to discuss this film, whenever the topic of greatest movies/ acting performances arise!Generations after generations after generations, this film should be considered as framework for Drama/Media/ filming students and people whom want to pursue an acting career.Joaquin Phoenix you are a legend! This was a masterclass performance and you deserve all the fame and glory at all the award ceremonies!

Title: The Irishman is less Scorsese than The Joker?

This is an entirely new take on the Joker so quit comparing it to Ledgers Joker.With a budget of 50 Million dollars, Phillips manages to pull off a phsyc-thriller film set in the 70s with actor Joequin Phoenix as the lead role of Arthur Fleck, the Joker.Phoenix in this movie is truly convincing. The music puts the audience in Arthurs head and the cinematography is superb! Costume design is great with everything in this movie being convincing and complex, yet not complicated enough to lose the audience.This is a must watch movie with many twists and turns, being in the head of Arthur Fleck is an incredibly unique take on mental illness. With scenes questioning and evaluating your own choices in life against other people , which is what every legendary film has managed to achieve.You will definitely not leave the theatres glistening with a joyful smile as if you watched the sun rise, but you will still be satesfied like every reviewer so far. Title: Phoenix is phenomenal

Title: Finally. Beautiful film is back.
Review: The most empathetic spiral into a rage fuelled desire to belong in a realistic, cruel but not-so-dissimilar to reality kind of way. Almost a psychological expose on how home grown terrorists feel and are made; how kids end up shooting up schools. This is how. Bullying, ostracism, falling through the cracks of society and extreme disparities in class and privilege lead to the breakdown of society. Brilliantly told and acted, it was reminiscent of Hong Kong's demonstrations (masks and rebellion against power authorities), Escobar-like villainous anti-establishment virtue with a V-for-Vendetta flavour. The best film I've seen in a long time. Didn't think Heath could be outdone but it was. Here's to hoping the Batman franchise is reborn with the same realism and darkness thats always been a tad missing, even under Nolan's direction. This is adult, gritty, real comic which has deeper comments on society and needs to be the new standard in comic based film. Logan (Hugh Jackman's final Wolverine) comes a distant second after Joker.4 out of 8 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

Title: Never judge a book by its cover!
Review: I was seriously not interested in that movie after watching some clowns roaming about in the trailer - I'm getting tired of the redundant Purge movies' characters, you know ; and I'm not enjoying the new trend of blurring the lines between good and evil (e.g. Maleficent, 2019). I just happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time when some friends opted for watching it, and I was baffled!The movie was nothing I had expected it to be. It is actually what a Joker backstory should be like. It is believable, intriguing and down to earth. It is really what you can call an adaptation. Todd Phillips manages to make you feel the darkness in Gotham and how it roves through the city in search of the next victim. The whole Batman universe is thus successfully explained. And Joaquin Phoenix is perfect in the role of the Joker.This movie is not really for the usual Batman fan in search of fantasy, fight scenes and high-tech accessories, but for the pragmatic moviegoers who can enjoy watching a masterpiece just like others enjoy French cuisine in a 5-starred restaurant - I'm not kidding! Great job!

Title: A Unforgettable, Profound, Deeply Moving Masterpiece
Review: This movie was simply beautiful, a masterpiece for all time. I think the reason why so many of us feel pity and - yes - sympathy for Arthur is because to one extent or another we have all experienced tragic moments and sorrow like he has, but we were able to pull out of our dark moments. Unfortunately, he never did.It is a truly realistic portrayal of how a cruel society can send essentially good person into the darkest depths of madness. The movie will not once let your mind drift into distraction as it is mesmerizing and fascinating from the very beginning to the very last moment. Despite the violence, you cannot help but feel for Arthur Fleck - Joaquin Phoenix's character - and may actually root for him, cheering him on in the hope that somehow everything will eventually lead to some form of happy ending for him. You'll have to see the movie to find out if it does.As for the movie reviews, some have been entirely unfair and biased for some strange reason I cannot fathom. One critic from a well known New York publication (btw, I'm from NY, too) criticized it for not being "fun," which makes it absolutely clear that guy has no idea what this movie is about and should probably dedicate himself to something else. If someone is out to see a "fun" movie, this masterpiece is not for you. As someone said in another review below, other movies are like going to eat a hamburger; this is more like a $1,000 steak. Fortunately, the success of movies by and large do not depend on film critics but rather on the general public and what we think about them.Regarding the references to Heath Ledger, with all due respect, it's like comparing apples and oranges. I saw his performance, and it was decent for entertainment purposes. But Joaquin Phoenix's performance is simply breathtaking and perhaps unlike anything ever seen before in movie history; Joaquin Phoenix descends into actual madness before our very eyes. He takes us an a journey through the human mind, with moments of light and moments of sad and disconcerting darkness, all while winning over the audience and getting it on his side. It's a depiction of life that we can all relate to in one way or another, which is why his performance is so unique.In terms of movie directing, Todd Phillips needs to be given credit, as he should be for offering us such a masterpiece. I'm sure it will mark and change his directing career.Finally, this is a movie I will see again, and again, and again to the end of my days. My former favorite movie of all time was Planet of the Apes (1968) because it had a deep message about the world and society, one I could relate to even though I was born years later. I think 'Joker' will replace it because it has touched me so deeply. I will simply say it had such an impact on me that I couldn't help but get emotional more than once.

Title: Masterful, dark, shocking, and strong. An incomparable work, the film of the year.
Review: Joker is a unique, raw and special movie. It is a violent story that shows us the slow descent into madness of our protagonist, Arthur. The movie was incredibly hyped to what runs the year, however, unlike what usually happens with many movies that cause such excitement, this achievement exceed any expectation. This is a movie that definitely deserves any possible ovation to her. An incredible job. It seems fantastic to me to know that the director was able to carry out a work of such quality that it will simply become a milestone in the years to come; it is a unique story, without censorship which shows us the development of a protagonist in such a fluid, effective and fascinating way that we can come to sympathize with such madness, a violent madness, raw and emotional. These words can describe the essence of this film, capable of transmitting ideas and sensations of extreme power and power that nothing can equal.Much has been said about Joaquin's performance, and here I come to repeat the same thing, because he simply deserves it: It's incredible, it's perfect. This is the Joker that is capable of existing in this world, a performance as strong as human, a cruel and realistic touch gives enough support for us to understand the motivations of the character, who is not only a villain with a goal, or an idea, it is the explosion caused by the spark of madness. The acting is just sublime, and I'll say it at once; it's time for his Oscar.Incredible, fantastically dark, every minute of this film is a work of pure passion, effort and attention to detail, you can more than notice the incredible work that has been put into it. Everything is simply fascinating, the direction, the incredible script, the beautiful cinematography, the masterful performance, the deep soundtrack, the emotional scenes, the fluid development, and so on.Joker is a masterpiece. Psychological, powerful, crazy.

Title: Awesome, mesmerising, masterclass in acting.
Review: Wow, in the words of the song, I wasn't expecting that!I thought it would be like Batman but there is nothing comic book about this!I'm a mental health crisis nurse with 21 years experience and I'm sad to say that this is a true reflection of community care as a result of years of the Tory regime.We used to have case study videos at Uni but this tops them all.It is the perfect portrayal of a man with antisocial personality disorder who is consistently let down by the system and slips through the net with disastrous consequences.Everything about this film is genius.Mr Phoenix, words fail me, apart from he is one magnificently gifted individual. A breathtaking performance.The film is very very dark, very very depressing but so gripping and engaging.Ignore the hype about people walking out and the glorification of violence, it's nonsense. Watch the average horror movie and that will be much more bloody and violent than this and if anyone were to wear a clown's mask and try to copy then they are seriously in need of help.Don't watch this if you're expecting a typical comic book film, but if you're after an adult, mature and true to life character depiction, then watch this.Awesome.

Title: Why you should absolutely see this movie
Review:
I Was not expecting this movie to be such a masterpiece at every single level. It is truly what a movie should be: transporting you in the psyche of someone that is not you and make you relate to this person in some strange way. I'm speechless by how incredible it was, how I was taken by surprise...
We knew Phoenix to be a great actor for twisted vilain since Gladiator , but now it is going to be impossible to imagine the Joker without him playing it.
There is such depth in his acting, such a raw interpretation of mental illness. I'm just baffled how he is able to carry the movie and this level of intensity from the first minute to the last one on -almost- a stand alone performance. Very impressive performance that make some A list actors look like amateur who can only play themselves.
As an origin story for the joker, it brings so much depth to this DC character and thinking of the Joker now in previous Batman movie, make him become such an interesting vilain.As a final note, I loved how they twisted the birth of Batman and kept the previous work done with Batman begins coherent but slightly different.I thought before that DC was doing a poor job transposing their universe and character to the big screen (except for Batman Begins) but man, this movie changed my mind!
Congrats to all the team who work on making this move a reality, and a standing ovation to Mr Phoenix for granting us of such an acting performance.
Already a classic!

Title: Dark, Deep, Moving, and a Psychological Masterpiece
Review:
As a student of psychology, Joker has found a way to see the slow decay of a individual suffering from psychosis, psychotic tendencies, narcissism, the need to belong, and finding pleasure in the darkest of places.
This movie isn't for everyone. It is very dark. There isn't a happy ending. Yet the acting and story-line can be appreciated for the moving story it portrays. As the Joker portrays one with a severe mental illness, this movie at least offers insight on the real struggles that exist in those with mental health problems, while still offering a masterful way to depict the origin story of the world's greatest super villain.

Title: The Taxi Driver of Comicbook Movies
Review: Joker is a Taxi Driver type moment for the Comicbook movie genre its just as nuanced just as controversial and just as dark, violent and dirty as Martin Scorsese's 1976 masterpiece, it also has deep deep threads linking it to a whole host of other mid to late 70's and early 80's classics like Friedkins The French Connection or another Scorsese classic The King Of Comedy its abit on the nose with some of its influences but it never takes away from the overall originality of Phoenix's performance or the movie in general it feels more like Todd Phillips paying respects to a wonderfully provocative and risky era in filmmaking, Todd Phillips is really masterful and mature with the camera here his direction is steady when needed and slightly more chaotic in chase sequences like William Friedkin with his chase scenes in The French Connection, Phillip's use of the close up here is much appreciated to so you can see and feel every facset of what is an absolutely riveting performance from Joaquin Phoenix he channels so much energy into Arthur so much so Phoenix vanishes for 2 hours and it's only when the credits role you realise he was acting its astonishing work well worthy of an Oscar nomination if not a win although knowing the hacks over at the Academy they will no doubt buckle under the pressure of media outrage and deny him. From the powerful score by Hildur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir to the wonderfully framed and gorgeous Cinematography by Lawrence Sher Joker is a rare treat not often seen in cinema today yet alone in the Comicbook movie genre it's a fantastic movie and it should be seen by as many people as possible so we can get more challenging and nuanced films in what is such a rich and deep universe. Joker is The Taxi Driver of the Comicbook Movie its bold, dark and controversial and we need more movies like it. 10/10 A Masterpiece.

Title: Best Movie of the Year
Review: There are many things that can be said about this movie, and going in there was a lot of talk about social commentary and how the movie will spark a violent event, but not one thing came across as something trying to trigger someone into acting out against society. It's just a movie, and a great one at that. I don't need people deciding my morals and movies don't either, it's just for entertainment, and this just that, but in a very uncomfortable way. I have never seen someone carry a movie in such a way that Joaquin Phoenix did. The way he moved, the way he held himself, to the way he contorts his body in an visibly painful way. It just screams commitment and pure talent. I just wish it wasn't a standalone film. The violence and gore in the movie is only in like 4 scenes but with such surprise and effect that those few scenes are burned into your memory. Robert Dinero gave a wonderful take on being a daily night time show host, and really is the best performance in a long time for him. This movie was truly uncomfortable, emotional, and really showed every layer of joker that really was never shown before. Every part of the movie slowly progressed Arthur Fleck into the joker, and if any part was removed, then the joker wouldn't have made any sense. It just shows how perfectly done the character arch of Joker was. I don't think there will ever be a movie with such respect to detail to the chain of events that led to his final form as Joker.

Title: A Chilling Ballet of Mental Illness, That Dances Between Life's Tragedies
Review: The Joker is not a comic book movie, but rather a master class in character study. The film follows your lead Arthur Fleck or "The Joker". You're told the story through his eyes, and through this lens it is easy to find Arthur extremely sympathetic. Jaoquin Phoenix's portrayal, coupled with Todd Phillip's writing had made for a character who holds onto your attention the whole film. There wasn't a moment of the film I wasn't in awe, when the score would slowly creep in to give you chills over a scene that was previously completely silent, or still shots of hallways, and stair cases as Arthur is alone in frame, just to give you a gripping sense of loneliness throughout the film. Though the plot can be fairly predictable, it's how those moments play out that are surprising. You feel like you know something will happen one way and it does happen never in the way you feel it will though. The script can often times be dull for some, but to me I saw these moments as cold, hard bits that look into Arthur's psychy. Like a scene in which Arthur is in a comedy club and doesn't get what's funny and what's not so he just laughs, none of the jokes are really funny, but they're supposed to be things we know are supposed to be funny so we see that Arthur doesn't understand. There are other jokes that aren't laugh out loud hilarious, but are just funny enough to get you to think they are, and then immediately, a like of dialogue comes in to make you feel bad about laughing about that.The best things I can say about this film can't be said without spoiling it, all I can say is that it is a cold, gritty horror film about the horrors of the human psyche that'll leave you uncomfortable towards the end, with many questions about yourself left in your head after just one viewing.

Title: Send in the clowns.
Review: Thanks to it premiering on the festival circuit and all of the recent discourse surrounding its content, Joker is a film that feels as if it has been out for ages when in fact it's only just been released this weekend. My anticipation for its release was already sky-high but had only been heightened by the media claiming it to be a dangerous film to release to the public and the rise in security presence at recent premiere screenings in America however, does the film even deserve all the discourse it's seen before its release?Having been disregarded by society, Arthur Fleck (Joaquin Phoenix), a clown-for-hire, descends into a life of crime and infamy.There's a deeply unsettling sense of impending violence that flows throughout Joker from start to finish, Arthur's descent towards a life of crime depicted in incredibly visceral fashion. It's a ticking time-bomb of a film that hones in on the mental state of its titular character and how he's viewed by society, Todd Phillips and Scott Silver not holding back in making Gotham a horrible place for Arthur to reside.The production design ensures Gotham feels very much a character playing a part in Arthur's downward spiral, as does Lawrence Sher's glum cinematography and Hildur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir's minimal yet rather haunting score.Joker is elevated to great heights by a mesmerisingly magnetic lead performance from Joaquin Phoenix, who yet again showcases why he is arguably the best actor working today with a performance for the ages. It's such a devastatingly beautiful performance that's both hard to watch at times yet hard to take your eyes off, Phoenix surely the man to beat come awards season.He's certainly the main attraction on show in Joker but he's dealt some stellar support from the likes of Robert De Niro, embracing the cheesy flair of his character, and Zazie Beetz, offering Arthur a glimmer of hope in his otherwise downbeat life.Joker really is a stunning character study from Todd Phillips, unflinching in its approach and deeply unsettling in its execution, the performance from Joaquin Phoenix in particular making it a film that will certainly leave a lasting impression.

Title: My Quick review over the movie
Review:
I watched Joker on IMAX yesterday sitting on the the best seats which means that I already known that this movie is gonna be amazing. How? Well, I watched the Master months ago which the only thing that in my eyes was well to watch, it was the Phoenix's acting in this movie.
This ensured me about his acting skills and his integrity as an actor that this movie is gonna be amazing. I was expecting something as good as this Joker, which it has honestly gone over my expectations. Firstly, Todd Phillips has done a masterpiece. Congratulations to him. He can boast anyone with this perfect directing of his. It is clear enough from the movie that he did not consent to any bad impression, any bad part that could be showing this movie as an ordinary film throughout the world. He targeted his efforts to create a perfect movie, to be a part of history. I believe he has achieved it already.
Secondly, the music of this movie just fits the mood and angles of the movie. This is one of the most important and common parts of any amazing movie. For Example, Interception would never be The Interception without Hans Zimmer making the music. Well in this movie, also I have seen great moves from a composer, which it definitely helped me to feel the emotions of such complex character (Joker), plot and the mood of each scene of the film. It is a well done composing by Hildur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir. She deserves some great awards for her art in this film.Thirdly, the script and plot of the story which makes the audience to be fully concentrated on the character of Joker and his feelings. It is more dramatic than a "DC" or a "comic" movie. This plot answers many questions about Joker's originality. The plot is amazing as well in which it keeps you guessing about the future scenes. Also, the fact that even after the film, it keeps you thinking about the theory after the ending and the moral of the story, makes this work of art, a special work of art.Fourthly, the coloring of the movie, the filmmaking, the screen display, the camera shots, the sounds, the special effect, the lighting and etc. All of them has don't the best they could do and make a stunning result. There is nothing say about them else than admiring the whole crew for bringing such an art to our eyes.
Lastly, The ACTING. For me, personally, I don't like a slow going plot. A smooth story telling plot is super boring for me. But, for this movie, the only and only thing that keeps me watching the movie without blinking is Joaquin Phoenix. His acting is just WOW! The most impressive thing about this movie, the most significant thing that make the movie, looks realistic is his indubitable, indisputably acting. His acting is phenomenal. For me it's just a question, HOW DID HE DO THAT??!! I can never act like that. It is super difficult to even understand the Joker's character. How did he act like that?! I believe This is his best roll ever, and one of the best actings ever. (At least in top 5) He deserves to get the best awards for his roll in this movie, and he is definitely comparable with Heath Ledger. His acting is full of emotions, filled with unreleased anger, full of simplicity and humanity, filled with oppression, his laughs are with meaning, his eyes are full of un dropped tears and his chest is full of unspoken words. He doesn't understand the people. He relies on their humanity, he trusts them and yet, he gets beaten by them, he gets betrayed and he gets suffocated. He has never found Love he always wanted. Everyone, disrespected him and manipulated him through his life. He has seen insincerity hurting him to his bones. And, when he gets to the top, when he finds his way to feel better, to be recognized, you can still see that he is confused and new to this stage of life. This is just perfect. One of the best actors of all time, I would name him.The moral of the movie is so deep and it is full of unfortunate and painful truths. It's an unreal but at the same time real tragedy.This movie can change a lot of people's mindset in different countries. If you have seen this film, please stop judging and discriminating other people. If you have not, you are missing a great masterpiece! Enjoy!

Title: One of the most gripping cinema experiences in years
Review: I was never overly hyped for this movie, though the expectations after seeing the first trailer were high. After seeing it at the opening day, it definitely surpassed any expectations I had. Yes, the title might be read and experienced as the Taxi Driver of 21st century. But at the same time it is much, much more. The best Joker movie that could have been made, dark, enthralling, moody, making you constantly uncomfortable. Great acting from Joaquin Phoenix, total embodiment of the loneliness, fragmentation and psychosis of the character and its slow turning into the clown prince of crime. By far the best movie based on comic book material and characters that has been ever made, surpassing what Nolan did in his trilogy. Though Ledger was great in the Dark Knight, the one that truly captures the essence and psychology of the Joker is this performance of Phoenix. A must seen movie, whereas the controversy around the themes of violence, anarchy and disputing of the existing order and paradigm in society should not be something that stops any true cinema lover from seeing this - go and experience for yourself a new landmark in the transfer of the comic books material to the medium of the 7th art. A true masterpiece of modern cinema.

Title: Just....wow!!!!
Review: Just came back from seeing this film and feel that my high expectations were exceeded. Joker is a rarity I feel. It is a commercial film that is taken from a comic book character but actually has something to say. It is by far the best DC film since Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy but it feels less like a comic book film than a character study. And it is. And yes I have read that it has been said that it borrows heavily from Taxi Driver and King of Comedy and it does in that it presents the Arthur Fleck character as a loner, outsider, mostly shunned by people around him just like Travis Bickle and Rupert Pupkin. It is definitely a film that follows that slow burn into insanity and violence like those films but it's not a bad thing.By now everyone knows that this film stars Joaquin Phoenix as Arthur, and through the film we see his transformation into The Joker. It is an origin story. He plays Arthur as a thin, weak disturbed person who is treated badly by those around him. And he slowly grows to have truly disturbing thoughts and actions. The film is a comic book film in that it is about s character that comes from that medium but it is in no way a light film. Avengers Endgame this is not. And I revere that film but i think that it is great that they decided to not sugar coat this story and tried to go deeper and make it more about the psychology of the character as opposed to his criminal antics. That Todd Phillip's a comedy director took this on and did it with such success is stunning. I will avoid all.of thr controversy that has come from this film saying that it condones violence. It is violent and disturbing but in no way compares to other films that are much worse. I like that it went for an adult theme and is rated R. My kid will.not be seeing this anytime soon. Great film, great performance. Period.One last thing. I know that Phoenix's Joker is inevitably going to be pit against Heath Ledger's interpretation of the character. Some saying that this is better. I think that it is different, not better. Ledger was THE JOKER. Joaquin Phoenix plays Arthur Fleck becoming THE JOKER. The performances stand on their own as great but I still favor Ledger just a bit more. But not by alot.

Title: Complicated, DEEP, different, unusual and thought provoking!
Review: Let me start by saying that when I left the cinema, I felt that I liked the movie a lot, and at the same time I felt disgusted by it. Maybe it's the portrayal of a broken man that has been put over the edge and gets really violent and crazy that left me feel that way.This movie offers a LOT of things to think about about our society, about our life in general and the way we treat the weak among us. I think this movie TRULY depicts how a psychopath is formed and the consequences this brings.The Joker is not "likeable" character but in many cases I think the public can explain his actions as being reasonable and logic.The movie is very, very, very deep and it's not just for entertainment purposes. I advise the public watching it have the mindset that they will be watching something truly different and not think of it as the latest Hollywood flick, because it is not.The movie is so deep I believe you have to watch it 2-3 times to grasp it.The acting is not great - it's UNBELIEVABLE! Joaquin MUST win Oscar with this. Movies like this are very rare and far in between. I hope more people can understand it because this is a complicated movie and I fear the broad audience won't grasp it's meaning.

Title: To be worth arguing about
Review: A movie must first of all be interesting: it must have, if not a coherent point of view, at least a worked-out, thought-provoking set of themes, some kind of imaginative contact with the world as we know it. Besotted with the notion of its own audacity - as if willful unpleasantness were a form of artistic courage - the film turns out to be afraid of its own shadow, or at least of the faintest shadow of any actual relevance.4 out of 8 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

Title: This may be one of the most important works of mainstream art in our time.
Review: The only emotion I was able to understand after watching this film for the first time was disturbed. It invoked one of the longest and thought-provoking conversations I've had after watching a film. One of the biggest being its portrayal of mental illness, which may have been the most realistic I've seen, and the graphic violence. Only after watching it a second time did I realize how little violence there is in the film. The way Todd Phillips was able to make the viewer feel so strongly about the protagonist's journey throughout is a testament to him, Joaquin Phoenix and anyone involved in the film, especially the way the cinematographer used colors. It balanced an original story and comic book origin story flawlessly and after the second viewing, was able to look past it's 'not so' graphic nature and understand everything Arthur was going through and was somehow able to empathize and disagree with a character at the same time as they slipped into madness. This may be one of the most important works of mainstream art in our time.5 out of 11 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

Title: "The worst part of having a mental illness is people expect you to behave as if you don't"
Review:
First of all I'd like to say "HATS OFF TO TODD PHILIPS AND JOAQUIN PHOENIX". If you're a cinephile and haven't seen this movie on the bug screen, you're missing something!
The movie explores the life of Arthur Fleck and shows us how an ordinary man becomes the JOKER.
Daringly dark, this movie left me and many others speechless! No one was clapping when it ended, because the movie itself is a slap on the face of society! Everyone EVERYONE is a result of circumstances. This movie doesn't care about anything, it doesn't sugarcoat lies, it doesn't confuse reality with fiction, it takes the reality and puts a fictous yet amazingly real-like story in it! Do we take mental illness seriously? NO. Does this movie warns us of the consequences? YES. Should we relate to this movie and feel sympathy for Joker? NO. You know what ignorance and suppression leads to? It leads to JOKER!
Coming to the cinematic aspects of the movie, believe me when I say this, "Joaquins acting was TOP TIER"! Credit goes to Todd Philips too for creating an amazing yet dark environment and daring to implement this story! Cinematography was on point and in fact one of the best that I've seen! I'm saying this again because no matter how many tines I say this it won't be enough, Joaquin acted as if he WAS Joker! This performance tops that of "Her" and will always live in cinematic history as one of the best EVER!
It would be needless to say that you should see this because YOU SHOULD SEE THIS!
Talking about my experience in cinema, I was shocked and SHAKING when the movie ended! The last 15 mins of the movie were one of the finest and intense piece of cinema ever made!
Joker shakes the society, slaps it's face, and puts forward a question, "Where are we going as a society?"

Title: This movie is beautiful, Joaquin Phoenix Would Make Heath Ledger Proud
Review: This movie is beautiful. The message they deliver is immediately felt: it's portraying our society as a whole in the movie. This shows us exactly how some people are treated with disrespect, and being completely isolated as if they're not even a human being.Not only that, but Joaquin Phoenix's portrayal as Arthur Flex is astounding. You can see the high amount of time, and effort he's put on to being this character. He really hits home in the laughing, shows Arthur's struggles immensely with society in every scene. Phoenix also does an amazing job showing the descent into madness slowly, which just makes you feel even more terrible for the character Arthur Fleck, and what society had done to him. He really might've made Heath Ledger smiling down at him, saying: "you've restored my Joker legacy".Speaking of the descent into Joker, that was also handled very well. We first start off seeing Arthur as a weak, willed character. He slowly walks up the stairs in a weird, almost saddened way. He has a shaky voice, and almost zero confidence in himself. Arthur was pretty much broken down: a human that society treated as non-existent.However, when he becomes Joker, we immediately see he's happy as can be, dancing to his own music in his head down the steps as shown in the trailer and the movie. He actually feels more confident, not scared to express himself, albeit in a twisted way of course.I suggest you give this masterpiece a watch, you won't regret it.

Title: Excellent example of mental health portrayal in film!
Review: Aside from the storytelling of how the Joker came to be, this film beautifully captured the true essence of what it means to be living with a mental illness in a society that struggles to accept and understand it. The inaccuracies and exaggerations that come with the portrayal of mental illness in movies are all things we are prone to see and unfortunately fuel the stigma surrounding mental illness. It's refreshing to see a movie that tackles that stigma at its core by showing problems with society itself and how society treats individuals struggling with mental illness. It's very possible to merge entertainment with education and this movie exceeded that. While addressing issues like societal judgement and unhelpful medical staff, we were able to see it conveyed in a way that was also interesting and entertaining to see. The aspect that resonated with me the most was when Arthur called his therapist out for not listening and asking the same questions every week. Another aspect I found particularly interesting was how even though Arthur made efforts to get help and treatment, he wasn't given help when his therapist informed him that funding cuts were being made and he wouldn't be able to continue seeing her. Keeping the momentum of going to treatments and trying to get better is a long struggle that takes a lot of effort and work. Not being given the proper resources or support to keep that treatment can also be extremely detrimental and many are unfortunately put in this position. There are many individuals struggling with mental illness that do not have the resources to get help. I'm glad this point was reinforced in this film because there are individuals that want and seek help but simply do not have the resources to continue or find it. What made this movie unique was its ability to speak to a large audience, not only those struggling with mental illness but also those seeking to understand those that do. One of the ways Joaquin Phoenix prepared for his role was he studied up on how to portray Arthur's mental health struggles in the most accurate ways possible. One of the best ways we can tackle the stigma is to show more accurate portrayals and working alongside mental health professionals or psychologists so actors can portray those characters in the most accurate ways possible. While there are no justifications for Arthur's crimes, we did see how lack of empathy and support influenced the way he saw the world. The world can be a very cruel place, but the most important thing we can do is extend a helping hand to a stranger to spread a little joy in the world.

Title: Disturbingly Realistic and Intense
Review: Wow. Joker is easily the best movie I've seen in a long time. I started watching it on my TV yesterday and was so disturbed by it I turned it off, not sure whether I'd finish watching it. Of course I did, today.What made it so intense for me, besides what makes it so intense for everyone, is that I worked in state mental hospitals for many years and personally knew criminally insane people. Also, I lived in Manhattan during the 70's and the mood, background and vibe portrayed in the film was spot on. When I read afterward that it was supposed to be '81, I was surprised because it appeared and felt so much like the 70's. Besides the shabby condition of the city back then, the whole political thread replete with looting and rioting suggested the great blackout of '77 and its aftermath, not to mention that iconic 70's film, Taxi Driver.As for Joaquin Phoenix's performance well, there's nothing original to say here. His portrayal of a psychotic man was phenomenal. In fact, I had a boyfriend in the '70's who looked like Arthur and while he was crazy, he was the picture of sanity compared to Arthur/Joker.Joaquin had a great script to work with. As a would-be screenplay writer myself, I have a great deal of admiration for Todd Phillips and Scott Silver. In particular the pacing of the script was fantastic, especially the way the details of the past were revealed well into the film. I experienced a sense of ah, now I understand, learning that Arthur's compulsive laughing arose from brain damage sustained during a beating from mom's boyfriend, also that he had a very painful and abusive childhood which explained a lot. There was an amazing sense of development and growing intensity of the character and his madness. Yes, it was somewhat predictable that something big and violent would happen at the end, but who cared? Even the ending was perfect, in my opinion.There were two things that I questioned: one was that Arthur did not use drugs or alcohol. That was certainly different, for the times and for a person with his extreme problems. The other was that the actress who plays Sophie I thought might have been too pretty and "clean" looking, meaning also not into drinking or drugs; her skin and eyes too clear, her weight just right, neither too thin nor too fat. It was a little difficult to buy that she would have been involved with Arthur and I was relieved when her attitude toward him changed.Joker is an awesome film and I think it will be days before I can stop thinking about it. It deserves every possible award it can get.

Title: Beautiful film, outstanding performance
Review:
**BACKSTORY**
If I had to describe this movie in one word, it would simply be "beautiful". From the cinematography, to the acting & improvising, to the outstanding score, Joker is by far my favorite film ever made.If you knew me before this review, you'd know that I used to always choke up when asked what my favorite film was. I could not answer, and any answer I gave was not sincere in the slightest. This one however, is.**IS IT A COMIC FILM?**
I will say this; it's not really a comic book film at all, it is *loosely* based off of the character "Joker", so you shouldn't go into this film expecting it to be 1:1 lore, but in my opinion that plays a key in making it so good. If this movie (in my opinion,) went with a more comic-like approach, I would not have enjoyed it as much as I do and I am certain about this. Take my advice, when you watch this movie, don't go in with the mindset that you're gonna see "Joker" the comic villain, go in knowing this is a film about a guy who just wants to make people laugh & smile, and is challenged by the harshness of the world he lives in. With this mindset, I can guarantee you will enjoy this film much more, just keep the DC lore to a minimal.I know what you're thinking, "Well then, why is it called Joker?"
Like I said, it's *loosely* based off of the villain, and just a creative take on his backstory. Other than that, I don't really have any great explanations for you other than I simply enjoyed the film better by looking at it from a real world stand-point.**REVIEW**
Joaquin's portrayal of Arthur Fleck was phenomenal! He reportedly lost ~52 pounds for the part, and it really shows during the film. The performance is INCREDIBLE. His uncontrollable laugh comes to mind, as in every scene it happens you can just feel the suffering Arthur is going through, there's a particular scene that I won't go into details about, but let's just say finally catches a break, and it's all ruined from his nervous laughter. These moments really show just how great Joaquin is as portraying emotion, you can feel every bit of the character's emotions through this film. Everything from his uncontrollable laughter, to his adorable kid-like nature, everything about this character seems real and genuine like he lost himself in the part.Joker would not be what it is without the collaboration of Joaquin Phoenix and Todd Phillips. Had Phillips not given Phoenix so much freedom, I don't believe this film would have been as successful and Todd know's this, he's acknowledged it in an interview with (I forgot who) by saying something along the lines of "You wouldn't be a great director if you had an actor like Joaquin Phoenix on and NOT allow him such freedom." Not word-for-word, but you get the drift.When you watch this film, pay attention the colors. The colors beautifully match the feeling of every scene, with the orange and cyan blue light's it really makes for a beautiful film, you can pretty much find a great still in every single scene that is filmed.**OVERALL**
I give this movie a 10/10 and I've never felt so sure about a rating in my life. I think it is perfect, and honestly I do *not* want a sequel, this film is perfect as a one-off and I HIGHLY recommend you see it in theatre's before it is too late, this is not a film you want to miss the experience of seeing on the big screen.

Title: What he did was wrong, but was it the right thing to do at the moment ?
Review:
The creative liberty given to the director/writers has given a new blend on the way you look at the joker. You don't need to be a fan of DC and/or the joker to engulf in to this epic saga of the journey of a transformation of a character. Every moment you have sympathy with the protagonist, he outsmarts you and surprises with the next move. The cringe it creates what happens next and results in another fiasco.All the time you ask yourself what he did was wrong, but was it the right thing to do at the moment ?
The so cleverly written movie was very well crafted and Joaquin Phoenix deserves all the respect on impersonating the soul of the character, Todd Phillip from his history of making movies has totally changed, He has become joined the big boys league now.
It would be a sin here not to mention clockwork orange and how someone is forcefully made into something, although joker here was more forced by the society.
And finally, Heath Ledger, the joker from the dark Knight, this was how a psychotic mind like him will become after few years past. Saying which one was better is a bad comparison to make. But with all respects to heath ledger, Joaquin Phoenix faced the gradient of character, which gives him the lead.

Title: Phoenix does it again..
Review:
I was initially sold on on its very first trailer, where I instantly realised that Phoenix's portrayal of Joker's humble beginnings would be another exemplary performance to add to his already prestigious filmography.
Now after seeing the movie in full, my assumptions are confirmed.This was a perfect example of how villains are made. How a history of abuse, trauma and neglect has resulted in a mental illness that has left our protagonist to function as a lonely awkward outsider on the fringes of society.
Most people in such a state are but a shadow of themselves, yet for men like Arthur, having hit rock bottom and awakening to the conclusion of having nothing left to lose, they set themselves free, allowing their alter ego to come out and play. And there's nothing quite as dangerous as a sharp and calculating man who has a few screws loose; loose enough to twist that moral code that most of us keep firmly intact.Although pure perfection, for me, would have it ending 5mins earlier, as he stood on the bonnet of that cop car, amidst the rioting, practically praised as the prince of anarchy. Had the credits rolled right then, in my mind, figuratively speaking, I would have stood up and given an applause consisting of five full-blown claps (that's three claps more than I'm accustomed to giving).I'm happy that this was the movie that the wife and I chose as our date-night outing. Last time we went to the cinema together was 7 months ago and were pretty disappointed with what we watched. But not this time. This time, we praised it all the way back home.

Title: Bucket list viewing.
Review:
I'd been resisting seeing this film for weeks watching others and admittedly not really enjoying any of them. Finally there was nothing else of interest to watch so off we went.
The opening scene of laughter triggered a painfully visceral sense of discomfort. Like being hit with a 2X4 I was awake and focused. Like many others I did not expect this and I did not expect this from Todd Phillips so my bad on both counts. Powerful, moving and brilliant in many respects this seemed like a curtain going up to reveal a whole new form of film making. I couldn't help think of Dostoevsky's "The Idiot" and how it could be re-imagined so that today's audiences would flock to it. Using veils such as "the Joker" might just be the vehicle to make it work.
I'm also bemused at peoples comparisons to Heath Ledgers Joker. While the connection seems obvious, I'd suggest Ledger and Phoenix's joker should be judged independently as standalone works of creative brilliance.
Strangely I'm suddenly not interested in watching other comic book stories after seeing the Joker be they DC or Marvel.
If you like myself had/have any preconceived ideas, set them aside and see The Joker.

Title: Worthy of all the praise it can get
Review: What is there to say about this movie that hasn't already been said? Joker is a meticulous, expertly crafted piece of art, in terms of writing, direction, cinematography, and especially performance. Every element of this film is a solid piece of the framework and each lends their strengths to each other in a way that hasn't been seen in a comic book movie before.From Pheonix's heart-wrenching, mesmerizing, and terrifying performance, to the tension building, tragic score, to the harsh depth of field that leaves the viewer in a dream-land, as if everything in the world is an illusion. There isn't a single element of Joker that isn't filled with passion and careful consideration. A week after seeing it and I've done nothing but think about each element more and more - it's a story that begs for repeat viewings, filled to the brim with detail, leaving space for theorizing and conspiring, the perfect way to do a Joker origin movie:"If I'm going to have a past, I'd rather it be multiple choice"The only slight downfalls of this near masterpiece is that in some parts it can feel a little repetitive, and it does heavily borrow from Scorcese films such as Taxi Driver & King of Comedy, but ultimately these are minor nitpicks in an unforgettable, unsettling, and thought-provoking narrative that will continue to be discussed and theorised for years.Filled with quotables, memorable moments, shocking moments, shocking moments with hints of Joker comedy, this is definitely the perfect Joker origin story, as well as an important message/warning to society regarding the 1%.

Title: Cinematic Genius
Review:
It's been 12 hours since I saw Joker at my local cinema and my head is still spinning.
I didn't get much sleep and I'm still trying to process what happened.
It was nothing short of a feast for the senses and I just wanted more.Make no mistake - this is cinematic brilliance at its highest level.
A masterpiece.
Hauntingly beautiful, magnificent, mesmerizing.
Stunning.
Chilling.
I honestly don't think I blinked during the two hours in fear of missing something.The onscreen world immediately captures you and pulls you in to an 80's Gotham City.
The thunderous Dolby Atmos soundtrack is beautiful, chilling and at times downright terrifying.If you are expecting a non-stop gore fest then you will be bitterly disappointed.
There are a handful of shootings.
What you will experience is a classic film of unprecedented genius, both artistically and technically.I must admit I went into the theatre with a bias towards Joaquin Phoenix.
Everyone has read the stories of his whacky antics and frequent meltdowns.
I'd seen his on set rant on talk show Jimmy Kimmel a few weeks back and thought him to be just another pretentious actor.
All is forgiven.
His performance in this film is truly breathtaking.Joker is not just another DC superhero film, it's a journey into the mind of a twisted psychopath who needed help but didn't get it.
For some reason, actors who have previously played this character (Nicholson, Ledger, Leto, Romero, etc.) have all turned in both sterling and mesmerizing performances.
But it's Phoenix who now wears the crown as The Clown Prince Of Crime.Here is my rather modest prediction come Oscar season.Best picture.
Best screenplay.
Best director.
Best cinematography.
Best actor in a leading role.
Best musical score.
Best sound editing.What I'm trying to say is this is undoubtably the best piece of modern cinema I have ever seen.P.S. For those uneasy about Gary Glitter coining in the royalties for his track in the film, his catalogue was bought out years ago by a UK based publishing company so he will not be receiving a dime for the tracks inclusion.

Title: Joker is a victim of an uncaring society
Review:
This movie is a story of mentally ill person being pushed out of society, abused by people around him and broken by people he idolize.
This isn't a some fictional story filled with CGI, and to some this isn't even a fictional story. There are lots of people who are treated just like Joker. They suffer in silence, their existence is treated as nuisance, their calls for help are called "toxic" or "privileged". Society so happily mistreat people, but then act in shock and horror when those people break.
Joker is a movie about pain and irony of the world. It shows how society treat those who are different and how it repays those who have dreams. This movie forces abusers to see the life of their victims, it shows the consequences of careless evil. That is why abusers and generally evil people can't stand this movie - because it shows them who the true villain is. Joker isn't the villain of this movie. He does lots of horrid things, the character should rot in jail for his actions, but shouldn't the people who made him suffer the same fate? Joker is a product of torture, so he lashes out against his torturers. Nothing more.By the way, it also have great comedic moments, but as Joker says himself: "Humor is subjective".

This is the story of one man's journey into darkness and that is why Joaquin Phoenix's Joker is easily the best Joker that has ever graced the big screen in my opinion.Will Phoenix win the oscar? Probably not. I can't see that spineless (Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences) politically correct tool of an organization giving out any major awards to a film this good.Joker is the best movie I've watched in the past 10 years. The flick gets 10 out of 10 severed thumbs.If you didn't already know the story centers around Arthur Fleck a mentally troubled comedian as he embarks on a downward spiral of social revolution and bloody crime. It is his story, it is the world as he sees it.

Title: Put on a happy face!
Review: You won't actually be putting on a happy face while watching Joker, what you'll be doing instead is witness the greatest film of the year and the Oscar-worthy performance of Joaquin Phoenix. His performance is extraordinary, every single time you hear him laugh, you know something is wrong and you start to feel uncomfortable, add all that to his facial expressions and acting skills and you've got yourself a perfect performance that will be talked about for years to come. What this movie does to its viewers is fantastic, you're on the edge of your seat through all of its runtime which is about 2 hours. Joker is full of shocking scenes and so many surprises and it utilizes its R-rating very well. As we know this movie talks about mental illness and what it does to people and how it affects them specially when those people get abused or be made fun of, and Joker portrays this so perfectly that you even tend to sympathize with the main character, not that he is a good guy, he's not, he's the Joker after all, but by the way of how they portrayed this, you will be able to relate to this character and understand what he's going through so that by the time his story comes full circle and you see his character evolve to the clown prince of crime we all love to hate and hate to love, you'll be very satisfied and upset at the same time by how he becomes the Joker and it's all in a good way. Joker has quite the Easter eggs and references to other movies like the King of Comedy and Taxi Driver as the director Todd Phillips said that those two movies inspired him to do Joker, so you'll definitely feel some elements of those movies in here too. Talking about this movie without spoiling it is so difficult, but all i'll say is this: Joker is a drama masterpiece and it's not like any other comic book movie that's been made before, this is an original story that is based on the character "Joker" from DC comics but with a new and a deep origin story that is basically a character study that'll leave you wondering and thinking about how devastating it is by the time the credits start rolling.Verdict: Joker is one of those movies that after viewing, you will need to sit down and try to take it all in because it dives deep into what mental illness is and how it can affect people and how society can be a part of that transformation.

Title: Surprisingly Excellent...HONESTLY

Joker Review, No spoilers
My rating for Joker: 9.5 !

For me, it was enjoyable.Do you think this joker movie will tie into Robert Pattinson's Batman movie?

Title: A work of art
Review:
I rarely give a perfect note but this movie deserves 100%. An origin story like you have never seen before. It seems so real that it could easily happen in the real world.
It points a finger to real life problems like desinstitutinalisation and the lack of help and follow up for people who suffer from psychiatric problems.
Joaquin Phoenix is absolutely incredible. He is not playing the Joker... he IS the Joker. His performance deserves an Academy Award. He is a method actor who transforms his body and his soul for his roles.
The cinematography (Lawrence Sher) is breathtaking. He is able to create a very heavy and dark ambiance that keeps us hooked. It's visually stunning. As the transformation of Arthur into the Joker advances, the camera makes the character seem bigger and just with that we can feel the confidence that he develops.
Todd Phillips has written, produced and directed was is, in my opinion, a work of art. The movie is heavy and difficult to watch at times. There are some very graphic and violent scenes but they are all necessary to the character development. I very rarely feel a deep internal unease as I watch a movie but I did as I watched how sad and tragic Arthur's life was.
The fact that they are able to make the watchers feel compassion for a psychopath is not an easy task.
The character development makes sense for once.
This is not a comic book movie. It's a character study.
Wow.

Title: Send in the clowns.
Review: One of the best aspects about DC's iconic Clown Prince of Crime, The Joker, is the ambiguity of his origins. Alan Moore's phenomenal graphic novel The Killing Joke (1988) provides us with one of the many possible origins for the character, but even Moore's renowned interpretation isn't considered to be the definitive backstory. Making his debut in Batman #1 in 1940, The Joker remains one of the most recognisable villains in the history of comics. Each appearance of The Joker, from The Dark Knight Returns (1986) to The Killing Joke, to Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on a Series Earth (1989) to Batman R.I.P (2008), and many, many more, stands as a uniquely different portrayal of the character, while still maintaining the core essence of his psychotic persona. Todd Philips' stand-alone origin story Joker is no exception. Arthur Fleck (Phoenix) is a party clown pursuing a career (unsuccessfully) as a stand up comedian in Gotham City. He lives in a rundown apartment with his mother, Penny (Frances Conroy), and suffers from a condition which causes him to laugh uncontrollably in inappropriate situations. Disregarded by society, Arthur slowly spirals into a life of crime, paving the way for the creation of his maniacal alter-ego, Joker.When it was announced Warner Bros. Pictures were developing a stand-alone Joker film, I was one of the many sceptics who claimed (with absolute confidence) that such an idea was unnecessary. Heath Ledger delivered an outstanding performance as The Joker in The Dark Knight (2008), and his portrayal has been long regarded as the highwater mark for those daring enough to adopt the role. Jared Leto's odd, over-the-top portrayal of the Clown Prince of Crime wasn't embraced by neither fans nor critics in 2016's terrible Suicide Squad, which led many to believe the Joker role had become untouchable since Ledger's critically acclaimed portrayal. However, in Joker, Joaquin Phoenix delivers an Oscar worthy performance as the titular character. Phoenix embodies the role perfectly; his performance doesn't mimic Ledgers (and rightfully steers clear of all Leto's shortcomings), and instead crafts a whole new take on the character while still maintaining the core essence of what makes The Joker so renowned. Phoenix brings a damaged realness to the role and embraces the sinister undercurrents of Fleck's mentally disturbed psyche. At times, he's downright unnerving. On occasion, I was reminded of Matt Dillon's performance as Jack in Lars von Trier's serial killer epic The House That Jack Built (2018). Both Arthur and Jack are mentally disturbed loners who harbour sinister urges, but what distinguishes Arthur Fleck from Trier's Jack (who, by all accounts, is a killer who isn't fumbling for validation in his crimes) is how he finds justification for enacting his own immoral sense of justice onto a society that has wrongfully disregarded him. It is important to note that you aren't coerced into rooting for Arthur as he descends further into madness. By no means is Joker portrayed as an antihero; you sympathise with him when the film begins, but this sympathy is short-lived once Fleck ultimately falls victim to his own heinous choices. From his maniacal laugh to his off-kilter, deranged mannerisms, Phoenix delivers a masterclass performance that would certainly make Ledger proud.Make no mistake, Joker is not what you've come to expect from the modern day comic book film. Philips and Silver have crafted a script that is grounded in reality and, at its core, it is a focused, psychological character study that trades in CGI spectacle (something that largely dominates comic book blockbusters these days) for mean-spirited, gritty nihilism. It's brilliantly constructed and certainly benefits from repeat viewings, as there is much of the film that is left open to interpretation. Hildur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir provides the film with a terrific score; it's brooding and eerily atmospheric, and stands as one of the best film scores of recent memory. It is a film dripping with atmosphere and tension that gradually elevates towards a finale that embraces the anarchy that Joker is known for. Joker has certainly garnered its fair share of controversy on the road towards its highly anticipated release, largely due to its violence and perceived influence it may inflict on audiences. While the film certainly has its violent moments, the violence never once overshadows the central narrative, nor is it as violent as the detractors would have you believe. What Joker ultimately serves as is a cautionary tale, while shining a light on how corruption can manifest within society.Joker is everything one could want from a Joker origin story. Dark, tense and fiercely gripping, it stands as one of the all time great Joker stories with a career best performance from Phoenix at the heart of it all. Destined to become a celebrated classic, Joker is this years must see film.

Title: That's Life- Fits in like a glove
Review: Joker is not a movie of pretense. It is about the truth.I think most people who disliked this movie disliked it because they were expecting some fairy tale, like they always do. But that's not the reality, is it? It hardly ever is. This movie portrays how much society can break you from within. This movie shows the struggle of a common man. It doesn't need any universe to follow, because it is a masterpiece on it's own.I went in to see a movie about this DC villain, but what did I get? I got exposed to the truth. It was certainly clever how the writers mixed a fictional character with someone who's living in this world and gave us something we kept thinking about hours after we came back from the theater.And Joaquin Phoenix's performance as Joker was as moving as the script. It was dark, it was bone-chilling and most importantly, it was brave. To portray a character like that, it takes guts. And he did justice.In all, it was worth it. Making this film was worth it. Received by many as a cold-hearted comedy, well you have it. That's life.

Title: Best Joker's body language thus far.
Review: Uniqueness of this production, when compared with Batman comic books, games and other movies, is undeniable. Joker's identity and his plans are very much the opposite of a mystery in here. This shift in perspective may just be what "Joker" needed to be the best movie based on a character from DC.For some reason, Joker is always taken very seriously by actors playing his role. Jack Nicolson's and Heath Ledger's Jokers were definitely phenomenal yet mostly acted by voice and facial expressions. It's fair to say that Joaquin Phoenix raised the bar by an order of magnitude. In his version of the Joker, voice acting and facial expressions are just minor parts of a bigger picture. His Joker moves like Joker. His Joker laughs and dances like Joker. It's very apparent how his Joker thinks, and he thinks like the Joker. He just feels like him. The level of immersion is unprecedented.Artistically, "Joker" is just beautiful. Music is perfect, Gotham feels enchanting but depressing, character costumes are very appealing. Whole experience is hypnotic, almost like in a comic book.Besides a true Joker and good Gotham, the movie contains some less important themes which aren't bad but may be distracting. It felt like they put two rather irrelevant scenes featuring young Bruce Wayne just for the sake of using the franchise. I also think that yet another version of Batman origins scene is the last thing a DC fan would like to see. All easily forgivable as everyone leaves their yaw on cinema floor anyway.

Title: A Masterpiece which would have worked as great even if it had not relation with the BATMAN Universe
Review: JOKER is a psychological study of the character, Not your regular comic book Movie. The movie forces audience to think deeply about issues regarding morality, mental health, bullying, the rich and the society as a whole. The main focus of the movie is the mind of Arthur and how it fragments apart under the many inhumane but impactful acts of the society which when pile up brings out the Joker in Arthur. What makes this hit the core of masses, is its relatability. He's a relatable kind of villain, bullied and sad. It also depicts how mental health issues are ignored by the corporates and the suffering people become even more isolated. Joaquin Phoenix has done a phenomenal job, even just looking at his laugh in which he has masterfully depicted the hidden sorrow behind the character, makes you realize that the man has worked hours and hours just to make this perfect. Cinematography was beautiful and the soundtrack suited the storyline perfectly. Even if the movie had no relation to the Batman universe at all, it would still have worked just as great. In the end, although you can't justify the acts of Arthur, but you definitely understand them.

You are very much instilled in the shoe of a person who has mental illness and has to face the modern day society who expect him to behave.. as if he doesn't !! For me this move is 1 step beyond another master piece called "Memento (2000)" which was also based on a mentally ill character. But Joker is an extensively Dark movie for a main-stream Cinema specially when he is dancing he is sending a layered message to the audience. Most of the times this movie gives you the feel of an Art Movie (more than just an action flick or superhero flick). The dark and disturbing part of this movie is sheer work of Art that too performed with utter brilliance. And last but not least, Phoenix is by far the best and most Realistic Joker ever.. for me he did a PERFECT job of not only Joker but also a mentally ill person.. Perfect expression, laughter and dialogue delivery .. In the End Please NOTE: that when i said 'mentally ill' i meant a person Not Fit for modern day hypocrite Society : )

Title: It's so much more than a character study.
Review: There is a danger to this film.An origin story, sure. But a warning about how society, friends and family can slowly wear away at a person - and how there's no time taken by anyone to understand anyone who is struggling, is different, who's 'failing'.Like driving and parenting, those who are poor at these things, seldom realise just how bad they are. With social responsibility and awareness, people are just the same. Everyone thinks they're good. Posted that suicide awareness meme? Tick. I'm a solid human being. Then post a video of that weirdo on the bus.The film has divided many. I suspect that those who've not enjoyed it are those with little empathy or those lucky enough not to have an ignored struggle to cope with. Certainly not adrift from society, or failing to 'achieve' (urgh). It's quite likely the film's closing line was a predictor of those reactions. I was the only one laughing at this and a few other moments.Phoenix cuts through his character's psyche here more than Joker does any victim. He breathes and cries loneliness. There are several moments which openly show his struggle to join in with a world he doesn't fit into. He waltzes through these and more, pulling you on-side and deeper and deeper. And I felt it. Very much.And that's where it could be dangerous. A potential call to arms.But above all, it's a remarkably engrossing piece, linking as much with King Of Comedy as with the Batman story. Drawing the links between the two worlds into focus too, and forcing us to question our ignorance and to challenge known truths.Phoenix will win Best Actor for this. Rightly so.
