Title: Finally a movie we deserve!
Review: Joker will draw you into his madness and sociopathy that will make you question everything. Todd and Joaquin bring us a masterpiece of human nature and how person is shaped by events that are happening to them.Joker is a dramatic piece that will be understood by regular people and seen in grey areas and not only black and white. It's about human tortures and dramatic events that happen all around us but we pretend like everything is fine. Joker dives deep into dark teritories and pushes boundaries with extreme violence but shows us why is everything happening and how our protagonist is dealing with information given to him. Arthur Fleck is a disturbed man which is evident from beginning but as story goes you find to learn more about him and how he is only trying to find its way in the crazy world.There are multiple possibilites for someone if they pursue them, they might not be the best but Arthur chooses one that he feels most comfortable with and his sense of comedy and darkness is unique but who are we to put his hopes and dreams down. Joaquin's commitmend to role is extraordinary, he pushes boundaries with his dedication for characters place and feelings. It is absolutely magnificent to watch him present us Arthur in all his colors and shades as he is mesmerasing, deceving and twisted.Todd moving from his regular comedy type movies and going full drama, choosing Joker (DC comics based character) and putting him in real world with real people insted of fictional universe is praise worth and him developing such a intriguing story that will feel like you are watching some regular drama inspired by time and day we live in. We live in sick and hard times but we choose to fight and overcome everything but there will always be other ones that are not capable of doing it and it will make them mad. Insted seeing this movie as movie that can make people do bad things it should make them see that bad things are not acceptable and how they make things dark and chaotic. and will always end in personal destruction.Directing and writing of Joker is marvellous from every point, it may not be the smart as some movies but it is captivating and makes you wonder all the time how things are going to happen and how they might have happened. Todd may have started his new path into greater film making and it will be interesting to see what he has to offer in the upcoming years.Dark, twisted and magnificent are the best words to describe the movie. 10/10

Title: Cinematic Classic! Heath Ledger would be Proud of This.
Review: This is an incredible achievement. It has the much needed depth for modern day movies and is equally gripping. The origin of Joker is as poignant as the origin of Batman himself. The seemingly unsmiling Batman who wants order does need, and indeed does depend on the equally mighty force of laughter and chaos that comes to be the Joker. The descent into disorder, the hatred of the successful, etc. is all seamless. I am truly glad that this movie held on to its darker tones as it is, after all, a dark Batman and Joker story. Order and Chaos. Bring it on. I do sincerely hope that they continue with this storyline and we see more of this intense stuff. 10/10 from me. Not 9. Not 9.9 but a full 10 out of 10.1 out of 1 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

Title: A Movie You'll Feel Honoured to Watch
Review: "Phenomenal" is the first word that comes to mind.It's rare to see so much talent in one movie. The style of direction pulls you right in to the dark world of Gotham city. It's psychological, it's gloomy and it's crazy, oh yeah. Without spoiling anything, some events in the movie are sure to hit you hard.The music is just perfect and makes the whole film smooth and much more effective. However, the best part of the movie is the actors. Every single character in the movie is portrayed so well, you'll need to remind yourself several times that you're watching a film. You'll find yourself doing a self sanity-check after watching the movie!Ultimately, there's Joaquin Phoenix. One thing I can tell you is that he deserves all the hype and more. The acting is at the next level. In my entire life, I've never felt so painful hearing someone laugh. The laughter, the dance, makeup, behavior and the personality, you will know no better "Joker". Joaquin DEFINES what this film meant to be.Anything less than 10/10 will be an insult to this masterpiece. If you don't carry a hatred towards psychological movies, definitely go check it out :)

Title: The Joker Has Arrived, And Its Brilliant!
Review:
It has took a 100 years for cinema to be where it is now and if Joker is any insight into this era of film, it's looking good. Firstly, Joaquin's chilling and haunting portrayal of a man trying to live his life while being broken at every chance in his life and every person possible is brilliant. The exploration of mental health not only by the writer but by the leads superb slowly dying eyes, his shallow and piercing laugh and his physicality being broken down into a skeletal structure laced with skin. This performance is amazing and as you walk out of that cinema room you will sit down and think "That is what the movies are made for." Although seen from teared filled eyes, the performance by all the cast and especially Phoenix and De Niro's performance as Arthur and Murray are some of the best in history with haunting and chilling moments that make you question who the good guy here is.
I love superhero films and i have very high standards when film making is experimenting with these established characters but my words are lost to the element of fulfilment i am at. The FLAWLESS script packs a punch with turns of emotion and surprise every second and it is a great way to use your time on this Earth and sit back and SMILE!. I wrote this 30 minuets after seeing this film and i am still overwhelmed but i can only leave you on 3 points:Leave this film as a solo outing and we can all be happy...You will never get another chance to see this in cinema so GO NOW!!Bring On The Clowns!DC have had a rough outing lately but this film has improved and adjusted what i fought was good cinema and i feel if you enjoy the art of film making, this film is a must see. 10/10.

Title: A terrifying masterpiece
Review:
Probably the best acting performance ever. And I don't say that lightly.
I don't remember the last time I watched a film and delved so deeply into the mind of the main character. It's scary, depressing at times.. but a shockingly real mirror on western society. From the smallest details in scenes, the viewer can abstract and pull real life experiences.
It takes the viewer so deep inside the mind of an indivudual who is confused on his reality vs consensus reality. We are taken on a journey of realisations, discovery of past trauma and floor shattering, life changing discoveries that even makes the viewer question their reality, their past and their capacity to fall into a confused state of mind. Once Patrick's floor of reality is taken from below him, he doesn't know how to react, his worldview is flipped and he is thrown into a freefall of madness. You as the viewer go there with him and the acting performance is so brilliant, you really feel all his anxieties and confusion of reality transferred onto you.A depressing film, I left the cinema is desperate need of positive thoughts.
However.. as one of the most important films of the decade I believe this film should be inspected and thought deeply about the problems in our society.

Title: 2019's Masterpiece
Review: Simple as that. Joker is a masterpiece. As a character driven origin film, this is the quintessential DC movie.As a film, Joker is incredible to behold. It almost feels like an honour watching some of the best cinematography and directing of this year come alive right before your eyes. Each shot is like a painting perfectly making use of the 80's athsetic.Joaquin Phoenix puts in a career best performance, equalling and some times surpassing Ledgers take in 'The Dark Knight'. Title: It was a journey!
Review:
I'm literally home lying down trying to digest what I just saw. This movie was a masterpiece. It definitely requires more than one viewing to truly appreciate and understand the masterful work. This was my first viewing so I'll hold off on throwing out any ratings etc, but let me tell you this: it was a journey! It was honestly the little things that I was able to notice that really convinced me of Joaquin's performance. And his ability to just throw that laugh out there off and on cue was insane. This movie is truly something special!
Phoenix did an excellent job capturing the essence of the character in his performance.
I actually understood the protagonist, his inner battles, his journey. It was Genius, pure genius. It was in my opinion hauntingly excellent, and executed with great precision.
They basically just made this portrayal more realistic. Although it wasn't comic accurate (which it wasn't meant to be), I was happy to see Joker go off and be his true maniacal self. In other words, that R rating did wonders for his character. Much like Logan!
My only issue with it is the fact that they made this masterful piece to just be a one off. Why can't they make a cinematic universe built like this? Just like the MCU.

Title: An afterthought from the time Hollywood still made truly great films
Review: I normally would cringe at the thought of giving any film a 10 rating, no movie is perfect and I guess this isn't either, but for me I suppose this gets pushed from a 9 to a 10 just for being the type of film that Hollywood just doesn't make anymore.This movie takes one of comic's most famous mad clowns and takes you with him on the soul destroying journey of how he became Joker. Don't listen to the online loonies, this movie won't make you attack anyone, it will however make you think about mental illness and the people who suffer in silence. As well as the general, but basic, concept of kindness to others.On this journey, though you often vehemently disagree with joker's actions, you're nonetheless compelled to understand those choices. Phoenix and Phillips don't just deserve Oscars for this, what they've created essentially amounts to a treatise on the more tragic side of the human condition

Title: A realistic view into a villains uprising - finally !
Review: Before I touch upon the content of the movie , I have to say the vibe it creates is like a Taxi Driver of the modern age with super villain in the making overtones ; which is funny because Deniro is in the joker , I wonder if the director did this purposefully ?Anyways , this movie was an amalgamation of emotions stirred up for a person I didn't think I ever cared for , aside from being a badass in a previous portrayal by Heath. Let's put this to rest right now ; Joaquin's Joker was so real to the point that I connected on a more personal level (than previous jokers including heaths) and I can see authenticity in this joker being THE joker that eventually faces off with Bats - even in this "depressing" formative period of his .... despite being exposed to an action packed super intelligent Heath Joker years before this .The feeling of powerlessness and a world against you is really what gets you down through your first 40 minutes or so in the movie but it's not a depressingly down feeling it's more of a contemplatively-down feeling for Arthur's condition and his situation in life . Essentially , it's hard to NOT feel for Arthur as opposed to what previous movies would conjure up in us for the joker - which always painted him as a one sided villain as opposed to the complex more than human Joker we see in this film.Overall the scenes were shot so well I felt like I was watching an old movie, which also helped complete the feeling of taxi driver (also that revolver Joker gets seems like a snubbed version of it), but also gave the setting of the film a perfect alibi - this WAS INDEED the time before Batman ; and we can tell from the scenery , the outfits and the props ... very well done. I feel although there's no promise of a sequel , the director and cast HAS to deliver a sequel - as the roller coaster ride of this journey has just begun and they really pulled the tempo of the film off correctly as to really entice us to be hungry for more screen time of Arthur In his very earliest joker years .If I could , I would see this made into a tv series as it seems so realistic with the way it displayed this joker , and the action was spread out enough to create suspense and many other emotions . If this was done I would expect them to cast Joaquin , due to his great performance , or at least someone that can emulate his exact performance and demeanor - as this was a performance I didn't expect to "attract" me so much as it did .Great film , 10/10 for me - if it weren't for the critics mindlessly bashing this title I wouldn't have written this review , but I feel like this is something we need to speak up about because everyone seeing this film either really likes it or LOVES it - BESIDES the critics ... hmmm I wonder why ? Maybe it has something to do with the AGENDA of those that wish to push a specific NARRATIVE for their platform? Look that's fine and all but please be a bit more transparent with your bias if you choose to run a review website .Compare the critics to the user reviews , how many of each one and you will see who the liars are and who is telling the truth about the movie . Everythings an "opinion" they will say after slanging dirt in an untruthful review ... ok that's fine but don't go bashing something that was shot , edited , directed , and written WELL and try to pretend like it's just some unbiased opinion, we can see through that !I, like thousands of others , went into the film UNBIASED and loved it , do the same and you will too ; go in there thinking the movie will have your incel neighbor boy kill you , you will leave there confused just to go on your critic profile on meta critic and bash for no reason and that will guarantee you have a bad time under the guise of social semantics .

Title: Instant Timeless Classic Masterpiece. Unbelievable!
Review:
First review I've ever felt compelled to write for a film...This film definitely lived up to the hype surrounding it and more!
After seeing Phoenix had been cast for the role, I was extremely excited as I've been a huge fan of his acting since his portrayal of Johnny Cash in Walk The Line. Never the less, I, like so many others was slightly sceptical that he may not live up to Heath Ledger's Joker but wanted to reserve judgement until seeing the film.
How wrong I was to have any scepticism. Phoenix's performance is for me the best acting I have ever seen in any film. Ever! I could not take my eyes off him on the screen in the cinema.
The film itself was much darker than I was expecting which I found really refreshing - tacking the issues surrounding personality disorders and mental health and how society can drive an individual to madness. Such a fantastic origin story that could simply be a stand alone film and still work without any links to the comic books.
I saw the film 4 days ago and don't think I've ever left a cinema feeling so utterly blown away by a film in my life. I have not stopped thinking about the film since and cannot wait to watch this masterpiece of film making and acting masterclass again.
Jaoquin Phoenix and Todd Phillips should win every award going when awards season arrive.
And I agree with other comments about Ledgers and Phoenix's portrayals not being comparable. But for me Phoenix's has just slightly edged it ü§°

Title: Joker rises like a Phoenix!
Review:
Below is the transcript from my video review on my YouTube channel, Slice of Pai. Please subscribe, would mean the world to me and I'm trying to change it :)The Joker. I'm not joking when I say this could be the first time that two different actors could win an Oscar for playing the same character.Now the Joker is one of the most iconic villains of all time, but do not walk into this expecting it to be a typical comicbook movie with blockbuster action.First and foremost it is a character study of the Joker, of one man's descent into madness, but the terrifying part was just how real it all felt. Arthur Fleck, A Fleck, Affleck? is a really sympathetic character at the beginning of the movie and you really feel for him when you see how mistreated he gets just for being different and misunderstood. Things just keep going from bad to worse for him over the course of the movie until he finally snaps when he gets pushed to the edge.And when he hit Rock Bottom, he rose from the ashes like a Joaquin Phoenix.
Because at the end of the day, this is his movie and he carried it with ease. He has clearly been psychologically scarred, his laugh is something like a tic from a neurological condition and he does have something of an Oedipal complex as well. You can see the Joker's physical and mental transformation when he embraces his madness in all its perverse glory.Speaking of physical transformations, his method acting reminded me of Christian Bale's. His emaciated physique was a bit like the Machinest, and parts of the movie also reminded me of American Psycho and had me questioning what was real and what wasn't.As the whole movie is shot from Joker's perspective, it brings some very interesting twists to the Joker and Batman lore. I'll delve into that more in a spoiler section at the end of this video.The film is also a character study of society as a whole, and although it is set in the fictional city of Gotham in 1982, it's still social commentary for today. Too many people tear down others to feel good about themselves, too many people want to see other people fail, too many people have no empathy. The movie shows the dangers of nihilism that is caused by all of the above, and it shines a light on the importance of mental health treatment.The film also brings credence to the expression "Don't meet your heroes", as the public personas so many celebrities have of wanting to help people are really just facades, which is something I've noticed as well.The film was excellently directed by Todd Phillipps and although it was a slow burn, that simmering really gave Joker so much nuance and complexity. The colour palette was very gritty and Gotham-esque and gave the movie a depressed ambience to reflect Arthur's.Overall I'd give joker 4.5/5 Pais, but I'm bumping it up to 5 for Joaqin Phoenix's Oscar Worthy performance.Have you seen Joker yet? What did you think about? How do you compare the Jokers? From Hamill, to Nicholson, to Ledger and now to Phoenix? Let me know in the comments below.Thanks for watching, but if you could hit that like and subscribe button I'll thank you even more. If you haven't seen the movie yet, this is where I say bye for now. But if you have, spoiler talk is coming soon.

Title: This is actually a REAL movie. Brilliant.

I can't even describe how I felt while walking out of the cinema. Feelings that I've not felt in a veeeeery long time after watching a movie, reappeared: Happiness, inspiration, deepness. Crude scenes were really disturbing, no horrible soundtrack, no horrible CGI, no shallowness.
The acting was incredible too; prior watching the movie I read some other reviews from "professional" critics and they mentioned a lot that the acting was too overwhelming; seriously, WHAT? I think they want some more generic acting or they can't understand what a mentally I'll person actually suffers and how they act. I don't know what is wrong with them, but THIS is the acting that the world actually admires.

I'm very grateful that finally we have a real movie.

Title: Welcome to the Emancipation of Arthur Fleck
Review: #JokerCaution: The slow burning schizophrenic emancipation of Arthur Fleck will leave you deeply disturbed, mouth agape in some scenes of pure violence, shocking you to the core.Arthur's fall into insanity is like quicksand. It will pull you along with Arthur down the rabbit's hole. You could try and walk out of the theatre but I doubt you will be able to move.For comicbook fans, Arthur Fleck eventually became the Joker, the one man who could not be moved, the one man who saw the evil in everyone. The one man who knew how to push even the White Knights into darkness, while he danced with the Devil in the pale moonlight (!) laughing away in his own terrible pain, his own deep frustrations, his own madness...This movie is about the final leap he took. The leap into sheer madness. You will become mad along with him. So compelling is this portrayal of the Joker.You could blame the apathy of a dying society for the final push. You could blame his mother. You could blame his colleagues.But in the end, Arthur doesn't blame anyone. Not even the demons in his head.By the end of it all, he learns to dance with them...You can see him do that dance in the end, without saying a word. His deep mad eyes speak it out as if he's shouting it in your face.It will shake you up. It will make you cry.Because you and I, are a part of the Society that drove Arthur to become the Joker...I have never been so disturbed by a movie. I've seen some of the most horrific movies as part of my quest for understanding cinema.This movie is a first. It brings tears to my eyes to write this. You will feel sad for Arthur's madness, twist your heart with the pain he felt.But you will also feel the sheer murderous horror that Arthur becomes. Like an Antichrist rising from the fires of our collective apathy and the death of our tired souls.P. S. To sit through this movie took all of my love for cinema. I have never been so much in awe, ever.

Title: He won my vote as the Joker
Review:
As a full pledged Batman fan (ESPECIALLY the animated series), my favorite villian has always been the joker...
Jack N was my favorite personification because he captured the "clowness" part of him...
I respected Heith L acting... but, he was NOT the Joker. He was too dark, to somber... too Emo.
But THIS movie wowed me!!
I dont know the kind of reaserch he did (if any) to portray him. But Joaquin Pheonix managed to capture all the key elements of the Joker in a way that makes it real yet maintaing the clown part. I can swear I see features/aspects or scenes from the animated series but grounded to a real life scenario... what would it look like if he was real? It cant be funny funny... he is a psicopath and a killer, but he thinks its all a joke.
Those easter eggs that only I saw, like a "its just a joke!"... "sometimes people just dont get it".
Plus more references made that justified obsessions...
His acting was AMAZING... you can feel his pain and desperation and why he would go crazy and hide behind his clown persona... and you pitty and fear him.
I could SO believe a Harleen Quinzel fall for Joaquin's Joker. NOT that gangster pimp ridiculous attempt.
Even if you are not a Batman fan and don't know or care about the story... you have to recognize the acting. It is a powerfull drama...

Title: Send In The Clown
Review: So Joker just hit theaters with a whopping amount of money being brought in for the studio during the first weekend.I don't know where to start when talking about this movie, so let's just start with the details. Joker is a movie about a psychopath in the making. It shows how a man suffering from a mental illness was transformed into the clown prince of crime that we all know now as the infamous joker. He has an uncontrollable condition of laughing at the wrong moments.The next point that I am going to make is about the reality of this movie. I believe that this movie was a call for gun violence bans, because it shows that in the wrong hands a gun can be very powerful. This was also a reality call in the sense that mental illness patients are not cared for as much as we should be caring for them, in other words say someone has physical damage everyone's gathering around them and supporting them but when someone has a mental illness they are isolated away from most people.Next up was the violence in this movie. Now the movie wasn't heavy on it but when it was there, there was a lot of blood. What made it worse was when the music playing made it feel suspenseful.After that, there was the feeling you felt when watching this movie. I am not going to lie to you this is a depressing movie, it is sad and he gets constantly beat up whether it's mentally or physically. It is sad and disheartening to see.Next is the director and actors. I believe Todd Phillips did a terrific job when directing this movie, he made it fit in with the comic book origins but still maintained a point of gun violence control. In my opinion he chose a stellar cast. Joaquin Phoenix was one of the best joker actors and, in my opinion, I thought he was one of the best actors, I thought he was at or better than Heath Ledger's portrayal of the ionic character. Another actor that was good in this was Robert De Niro when he represented a character that acted like the late night host Johnny Carson, Robert was outstanding in this movie.A movie that was like this. One of the movies that they brought in to portray this movie, Taxi Driver had the same gritty feel. Don't get me wrong both movies are really good but I believe joker was better.Finally my opinion of it. I believe anyone who just likes a good suspense movie should go watch this. It had a really good plot (not easy to follow, because joker imagines stuff), it had a massive play twists and it was just an overall good movie I would rate it a 10/10, best movie of the year. I am excited to see what the future holds for this version of the joker.Spoiler alert for the next section...My theory of what the ending meant. I believe that the joker was telling the story of the movie to the therapist at the end. He believed that he was the "Savior" that everyone needed, to bring laughter and joy to the world. Title: This IS the only Joker
Review:
This film is 90% Arthur Fleck and 10% Joker. That is not a bad thing because the facts are so organic as they unfold, this becomes the Joker backstory that you never knew you needed.
I'm a huge fan of both of Tim Burton's Batman films, & who doesn't love Jack Nickolson? But this Joker gets moved to the front of all the lines, and makes Heath Ledger's J look contrived.
I was never a fan of his interpretation.
Let's not even mention the one-who-shall-not-be-named in the most recent J in Suicide Squad. Trash. Complete trash.And, if you're a fan of Villain Dances like I am, this one is EPIC. It is awkward in the most real & vulnerable way and then rises to Mick Jagger perfection at the pinnacle.
Conflict & incongruity are what makes the villain dances so mesmerizing. My benchmark has always been creepy Mr Blond from Res Dogs when he's gleefully torturing the street cop, but Sam Rockwell always steals any show with his style anytime he's fulfilling his bad guy rolls. Joaquin and his villain dance aren't so forthright, it takes a few tries and he doesn't get it right every time, that's what makes the scene on the stairs so powerful & almost orgasmic. It's a glimpse into what his complete transformation will look like once he's embraced his alter ego, fully.
There's some other fun facts? that will shake up the DC Universe if you pay attention to details.
This film will absolutely be triggering to anyone who has suffered abuse, neglect, bullying, apathy from ppl supposed to help, or just downright inhumane treatment.
Send in the Clowns.

Title: "The worst part of having a mental illness is that people expect you to behave like you don't!"
Review:
Never did I expect "Joker" to have the impact on me it did! I went in expecting a grandiose, dark and twisted character study with a top notch lead performance and came out richly rewarded with that and so much more. Not only does "Joker" provide us with a unique take on the origins of The Joker, it also provides us with an in-depth character study on mental illness and the corrupt, narcissistic and anarchic society we all live In, but some of whom struggle to see, through their rose-tinted glasses!
.
The most important message I received which really hit me hard due to my own experiences with mental health and my own somewhat troubled past is the fact that anyone one of us could of potentially been or still could be a semblance of "The Joker," and Todd Phillips has, with this film, presented us with an articulate presentation on what personal trauma could possibly turn someone into the joker and what little is done to prevent such terrible things from unfolding.
.
I cannot help but think, wow, what if my life turned out like that, what if I went through all that pain and suffering, because it's real, this stuff has actually happened and is still happening all over the world. What kind of person would I of turned into? There's only so much a person can take before they snap, and once they do, could you really blame that person for breaking? Especially when the world is already broken. And when society shuns you to the side without listening, helping, supporting or caring, it's just like setting off a ticking-time-bomb, placing it in a busy crowd and then just waiting until it explodes.
.
Let's be honest, people don't want to understand or actually help, some are too scared to accept it and some are too up their own asses to even realise, and then when you finally feel brave enough to try and get medical help, they're just quick to label you with some sort of "mental illness," feed you some crap about how to "get better," prescribe you some meds and then send you on your way, most don't even care about knowing why you're actually feeling like this, and if they don't like what they hear or you're "too broken," they're quick to lock you up without bothering to find the true source of the pain and the actual cause or causes of said issues.
.
I'm not ashamed to say, there were times during this film where tears flooded my eyes due to the pain of Arthur Fleck. It truly broke my heart seeing, nay feeling what he was going through with no help at all, in-fact, quite the opposite; every kick in the gut was quickly followed up with more kicks to the gut, it is not a light story! The screenplay is constantly real, raw and quotable, constantly asking questions that really make you think. The score is riveting and definitely a highlight of the film, every chord that was struck shook me to my core, the soundtrack is pitch-perfect and the cinematography was beautiful and atmospheric.
.
There are truly no words for Joaquins performance, I was and still am completely blown away by his physical transformation and the authenticity of his character. Every scene he's in, just the look of his tormented face and his haunted expressions has you on the edge of your seat, terrified to find out what's going to happen next. How he manages to capture the true essence of Arthur's pain in one single laugh is absolutely harrowing and his delivery of every single line is venomous and of the utmost importance! If he's not atleast nominated for an Oscar, chaos will ensue, just like it did here!
.
The supporting performances where all perfect; they helped express the intensity and severity of the storyline and Joaquin's central performance. The brutality of this film is needed and personally all of the BS circulating this film is unwarranted. You cannot blame a film for potentially influencing violence because of its brutal and dark nature when it's giving a raw depiction of our world we live in now and when one of its main objectives is to shed a little light on what society could/should do to prevent these situations from ever happening. Everyone should see this film for the multiple insightful messages it provides, Joaquin's (fingers-crossed) oscar winning performance and Todd Phillips' unflinching direction! Must See!

Title: Heartbreaking and COLOSSAL
Review:
I have read a lot of reviews about this film commenting on the cinematography and the music (haunting) and the outstanding direction (Phillips) and acting (Phoenix) but none has expressed how utterly heartbreaking Phoenix's portrayal of a grown man who has suffered child abuse and neglect is - it is physically painful to watch - utterly beautiful and heartbreaking. I felt as if I'd taken him home with me after the film; his all consuming embodiment of the tortured man who is Arthur Fleck attaches itself to you like a needy animal and doesn't let go for days. And then only reluctantly. How he manages this is mesmerising. The violence in the film is gratuitous but feels inevitable and 'justified' given how he has suffered. It is of course coming from a sociopath who so clearly has been created by the neglect of a mother who suffered from mental illness, herself. The violence he inflicts is the manifestation of the utter rage and emptiness he feels. Phoenix lives this onscreen. This is what is so utterly devastating, exhausting, colossal and enveloping about his embodiment of Arthur . And it is an embodiment, not a performance. It's too real to be a performance.
I totally agree with another reviewer who says that if you're not willing to develop you're own thoughts about the subject in a film as dark and vast as this - watch something else. You'll feel it physically but you're brain will try to process what you've just been through, so be prepared.
Utterly transfixed was I for the ENTIRE film. Life changing. And utter kudos to the director and lead actor who were not afraid to show us mental illness and it's heartbreaking affects (extreme though they may be, here) and it's legacy, in all it's deep, dark relentlessness.

Title: A Masterpiece of Cinema
Review: Joker was the film I was most looking forward to this year! To be honest after the high point of Avengers Endgame, I was kind of feeling tired of all these superhero films. Even DC's Shazam (although a fun film) still felt very safe. However, DC had one more film up their sleeves that left me intrigued. No rhyme intended! JOKER! A film starring Joaquin Phoenix as the titular clown prince of crime. I'd always liked the character of the Joker, a phydistic clown who goes around causing mayhem.To me, there had been no definitive version of the Joker. I liked pretty much every interpretation of the Joker each had their own style. From Heath Ledgers mysterious crazed terrorist. Too Cesar Romero's clumsy clown. Heck, I even like Jared Leto's portrayal. That's why I was looking forward to see what Joaquin Phoenix could bring to the table.When the first trailer was released early this year, I was very pleased too see that this film was going for a dark gritty mature tone. It was a chance for DC to develop their most beloved villain with no restrictions. The Joker is insane and having us be able to see his violent crime would impact the general audience even more than any prior incarnation.The news that this was also going to be a standalone film with no connections to the DCEU excited me even more as the film could be itself without having to connect to a larger universe. At this point my hype was through the roof and it Id had to wait a few more months until I could see it.On October 5th I sat down to watch a film that promised to be an achievement in film. So after the film came to its conclusion I was left in me seat stunned. What a masterpiece!The film is an interesting intense depressing journey into the mind of the man who was going to become the Joker. It's about a man rejected by society and his revenge against. To me it felt refreshing to have comic book fill that felt nothing like a traditional comic book film. It felt like a psychological thriller. It felt refreshing. Not entirely new though. It took a lot of inspiration from Taxi Driver and King of Comedy and it is so obvious but this isn't necessarily a bad thing as it takes the best aspects of those films and greats a film which is shocking and thought provoking. The film is shot amazingly. Every shot has a purpose and it adds to the overall tone of the movie. Joaquin Phoenix is great as Joker and Arthur Fleck. You may be wondering why I refer to the Joker and Arthur Fleck as two different characters as to me these two sides of the same person are very different. And yesI'll say it again he deserves an Oscar for his performance. Robert De Niro is also an amazing addition to the cast he plays a late night talk show host called Murray Franklin and encompasses everything about a talk show host is about. He plays quite a significant role in Arthur's story and helps him become Joker. The supporting cast is also good but don't steal the show like Phoenix which is good because it's he movie.If your going into Joker thinking this is going to be your typical superhero action film your going to be very disappointed. Also, if you want to watch a film where the Joker commits crimes and antagonises the caped crusader this isn't the film for you. The Joker isn't even in the film to the very end of the film but boy is it good when he emerges. But I digress this film is about how the man becomes the Joker not about the Joker. Yes it's misleading to call the film joker but that's the point. However Joker is a marvellous piece of cinema and deserves to be given a chance. That's why I give it the highest rating of 10/10

Title: A mirror that nobody wants to look at.
Review: I'll let other people focus on the incredible cinematography, nuanced acting, superb writing and detailed score. It's all amazing in my vastly unqualified opinion. What I'd like to offer my thoughts on is the underlying, cultural importance of this stunning, Kafkaesque caricature of life in an often solitary bubble that we somewhat ironically refer to as civilisation. It is the story of a man stripped to nothing but the subjective will to power without restriction, √† la Nietzsche's 'Thus Spoke Zarathustra'. The introjected values that tether Arthur Fleck to society are diminished when they are not reflected in the behaviour of others that continuously overlook and mistreat him on account of his illness. He is relentlessly denied autonomy, agency, self-determination and subjectivity by a cold and abusive world until his climactic metamorphosis as this nightmarish, maniacal overman. I think the violence in the film speaks to a part of the viewer that we actively suppress because of our own introjected values and conditions. We leave the cinema and go about our day accepting that we've just witnessed an exciting, moving and deeply upsetting fiction. Yet in our dissonance between the aroused exhilaration and disgust, we are forced to acknowledge the very conditions that keep us in check within our role in society. It is a kind of thought experiment which ultimately highlights a very clear truth; society has a responsibility for it's own mental health, even more so to those that we have neglected and let down to the point that they break catastrophically. The upset and outrage inspired by the film is sort of the whole point. A film or videogame can't inspire violence in the meek, passive members of society who's sensibilities and expectations tell them that what they are seeing is horrific and unsettling. That's absurd. Equally, it can't inspire disturbing behaviour in those with the capacity to go out into the world and commit such acts. That darkness was already there, and it was foreshadowed by a lifetime of trauma and neglect. No, Joker doesn't beckon the bogeyman and instruct him to wreak havoc on the world. It simply holds a mirror up to society, showing us that the bogeyman is already here. We don't like what we see in our dire reflection because we were comfortable here in our faux, utopian soft play of ignorance and dismissiveness. It comes as no surprise that the establishment are already railing against this message, because they are the most comfortable of all. Let's not forget that we live in a world where pivotal books such Robert Cormier's The Chocolate War and Stephen Chbosky's The Perks of Being a Wallflower are still routinely removed from libraries. Yet, this bosom world in which we nestle is a fiction in itself. We value society because it offers protection, but what about the times when it fails? What about the neglected and the marginalised? Those that do commit radical acts of violence have ultimately been let down by the very social contract that promises to protect them, and it is on all of us to do something about it or accept our responsibility for the consequences. Joker is more than just a very important and timely admission of our shortcomings. It is a call to action; Not for revolution or civil unrest, but for compassion.

Title: An inward look psychological rollercoaster.
Review: Managing to stay true to the comics in an origin sorry based on the joker is tricky, due to the very nature of the character and the lack of knowledge of his former life which we have to go on. Without spoiling anything, much of this movie takes place in the viewers own mind. Leaving more questions by the end than you had going in, the movie manages to pull off showing us the Jokers history, while having us question if what we are seeing is in any way real, or if it depicts the character we think we all know. There are a few nods to the batman comics, but it isn't a batman movie in any way. Really, it isn't even a joker movie. It's a movie about a fractured mind in a fractured world, and it's self imposed confirmation, slowly becoming a character we both love and loath. Creepy, disturbing, intense. Phoenix really nails this version of the character, but also manages to capture the lonely, sad life of Arthur, leading us to fully understand, and both completely misunderstand the journey he takes during the course of the film.1 out of 1 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

Title: An absolute masterpiece. Critics are offended by this movie and here's why....
Review: I will start off by saying I had very high hopes for this movie, but was not expecting it to live up to the hype. Neither was I expecting Joaquin Phoenix to even get close to measuring up to Heath Ledger's Dark Knight performance. I will admit I am a huge fanboy of Ledger, so when I say that Phoenix blew me away and gave an equally amazing performance in this film and that this movie is probably the best movie made during this decade, I absolutely mean that.This movie is more than just an origin story. It's an in depth view of how someone becomes a villain and the factors that lead to it. To start off, yes, Arthur Fleck, aka the Joker, is mentally unstable and suffers a condition that forces him to laugh in situations he shouldn't laugh in. Mix this with his anxiety, he is put in positions that are extremely uncomfortable that he doesn't want to be in. It also doesn't help that his social worker doesn't listen to him and is disgruntled by the fact that the government she works for doesn't value her profession enough to keep it alive. Arthur Fleck is a good person at heart in the beginning and is trying his absolute best to be happy and make people happy. But as the movie goes on, his attempts to do everything in his power are crushed, and ultimately, he hits a breaking point, leading the Joker to become a psychotic murderer.This above mentioned point is why I think critics and the media are quick to dismiss this movie, because it does not fit the "guns and weapons" are the problem narrative. If you look at any tragedy that happens, what get blamed? The weapon, or ideology in 99% of the cases. The media does this because it advances an agenda that they align themselves with. Heaven forbid the people committed the crime was actually just mentally ill and just looking for validation for their actions. Or better yet, will get recognition and fame from, you guessed it, the media.Now, where does the Joker fit in to the above mentioned point? Why I loved this movie so much is that the Joker sees validation for his actions. At first, the first murder is shocking, he's scared, and honestly the first murders could be justified as self defense. But as the media portray's the support he receives, he starts to think that what he is doing is ok, and ultimately there are some people that view him as a hero. Why, because the media allowed this happen and society validated it by supporting him.Aside from this point, the movie itself is phenomenally done. This is hands down the best origin story to have been made. It's brutally honest, it's dark, it's violent, and very uncomfortable at times. Phoenix's performance is the best I've ever seen him do. He deserves the Oscar, and quite honestly this movie deserves best picture. But it probably won't win it because it doesn't 1) Say everyone that is white is a racist or 2) Have a liberal agenda. or 3) Say guns are the reason for mass shootings, 4) Say's "Orange man bad".Critics are out of touch, and honestly are an invalid profession. Critic is another word for "someone who gets paid to share an opinion." At the time of this review, the movie has a 9.0/10 rating from ~150K users, with a metascore of 58 from less than 100. Listen to the masses instead of the "Elite" who claim to know better than you. This movie is worth the viewing.

Title: The king is dead.. Long live the king!
Review: Despite the title, I'm not going to compare Joaquin's Joker with Heath's here. This is a different film altogether. Heath brought us a beautifully crafted fully formed joker in DK, JP however brings us Arthur Fleck in all his disturbed severely mentally ill glory. It would be like comparing a caterpillar to it's butterfly..It's much less of a comic book movie than a horror film. In fact in parts of the film I forgot I was actually watching the formation of the joker, as Joaquin pulls us so deep into Arthur's illness, it becomes impossible to relate that character to anything remotely 'comic book'.Joaquin Phoenix is exceptional in this movie and he has to be, there is no supporting cast as such for him to hide a shoddy performance, just transient characters that either serve to further provoke or highlight Arthur's illness. Todd Phillips did a marvelous job here of making all of the characters bar Arthur somewhat disposable, they exist but only as a tool for Joaquin to use to craft Arthur. Even Di Nero is a passenger here, his character just used as a catalyst for Arthur's eventual brutal full metamorphosis into Joker. With that said though he plays his role beautifully and it was wonderful to see that man back where he belongs in a piece of cinematic history. The climax of the scene between them is just a thing of absolute movie genius, crafted out by two of our times greatest actors.I'm not sure how the movie got it's 15 rating here in the UK. The violence though not continuous is disturbing in it's realism, indeed the whole film felt 'adult'. It's definitely not a 15 that I'd be letting my 13 year old son watch anytime soon. I guess it's a box office thing!In all honesty though as much as I loved this film, I don't know if I could give it a second watch. Maybe that will change over time but right now I feel it's a movie like the usual suspects or seven.. I want to hold onto the surprise of this film, because I went in expecting something entirely different to what I was presented with.Joaquin's always been a slightly underrated actor for me. He's been nominated for three academy awards, most notably of which were best actor for Walk the line and best supporting actor for Gladiator, but has won none. His portrayal of Commodus especially was deserving of an Oscar. Tell me a movie villain you've ever hated more than that? I struggle to find one personally!! He MUST get an Oscar for this performance!!

Title: Watch This Film!!!!!
Review:
I want to be completely honest in giving my review of this film. I am a huge fan of Joaquin Phoenix, but I was not very excited about this project. I believed the DC tales of Batman and the Joker were overly exhausted to the point they were no longer entertaining. I wholeheartedly thought I would hate this film.
With that said, I was completely shocked with the depth in story telling, phenomenal acting, and brilliant dialogue delivered by this film.
This is not a superhero/ villain story. This story goes much deeper into societal norms which are troubling and in many cases disturbing, but routinely go overlooked. This story dives into the psyche of a person who has experienced physical, emotional, and mental trauma at the hands of a society that really doesn't value him as a person and thus discards him completely as a sort of joke.
The politics associated with this film are very familiar and relevant to what we see and experience in today's political climate.
Some fear that those in power may see it as a threat towards the status quo, while those who feel oppressed may see it as a call to arms.
I completely understand why media is trying to discourage people from seeing this film; it is not because it doesn't deliver, but because it really does. This is a film that makes one pause, think and acknowledge that there are situations in this world that require us to be more human. It also opens our eyes to the class systems which still exist in our societies and how change is necessary to disrupt and eradicate those unfair and unjust systems.
I recommend everyone go see this film! üëçüèºüëçüèº

Title: First Impressions: One to Think About
Review: "Knock knock..."Joker is about Arthur Fleck, he's a disturbed and formerly hospitalized clown in Gotham City who lives with his sick mother he takes care of. He also has aspirations of being a stand up comic and is a big fan of the Murray Franklin Show, Gotham's big TV late night talk show and after a video of Arthur's bizarre stand up act gets shown on the show... he's invited to be appear on the show for an interview.So I JUST saw this movie....And... it's all still flushing around in my head so I'm having a hard time writing a proper review for it. I keep starting to write and then I start over and so on... so I wouldn't call this a review, more "first impressions".Because there's a lot to get into with this movie and there's things to discuss.I got home from Avengers: Endgame and knew exactly what I thought about it.Joker... I don't know, I need some time and maybe even to see it again. Maybe in IMAX which I can't BELIEVE Warner Bros put the time and effort into making an IMAX version of THIS movie...But... I liked it... might have even loved it.... but it's not perfect. It's not the R-rated Joker movie of my dreams.... which would kinda just be The Dark Knight but with blood. Like I already GOT my perfect Batman AND Joker movie in 2008 so anything after that is a nice bonus.There's nothing in it I disliked but... it never hit heights I would have hit if I was given the keys to the Gotham City kingdom. For one thing, it's a shockingly small movie, hence my slack-jawed reaction to finding out that right now people are watching this in IMAX.It's a psychological thriller, it's not a horror movie or a crime drama. It's a drama about an insane person.The movie it reminded me of the most wasn't even the Scorsese movies Todd Phillips says he was inspired by but One Hour Photo. This is a 2 hour movie where the only guy we're with is a complete psychopath.There's no hero in this movie. There's no relief, there's nobody trying to stop the Joker. So the worse he gets, the more tense the movie gets because we know there's no Batman or Commissioner Gordon coming to the rescue here. So this makes for a pretty unpleasant movie.Joaquin Phoenix gives an Oscar-worthy performance as Joker and he might even win for this movie. Is he better than Heath Ledger? No.... but it's SUCH a different version of the character it's not even comparable.... which brings me to maybe my main complaint with this movie....I think.... this movie would be a LOT better.... if it were not called Joker. I think knowing it's The Joker I had so many expectations of where this movie would take this character and that kinda hurt my first viewing.Maybe on a rewatch that'll go away completely but I kept thinking this movie would play better if you didn't know you were watching a movie about the Batman villain The Joker until the final act. Because I certainly kept expecting a lot more... Joker-y type stuff in this movie and it really doesn't tap into the Joker I'm familiar with.This isn't a criminal mastermind mixed with a serial killer with a permanent smile, it's not Nicholson's Joker or Ledger's Joker.... it's a whole new thing.It really is more of a Joker origin story than a Joker movie. Like this entire movie almost feels like the first act of a proper Joker solo movie. I REALLY hope they make a sequel because as much as I enjoyed elements of it I wanted way more.Lack of Batman is not the issue here at all, by the way. Joaquin Phoenix does more than enough to carry the movie on his own but.... at the end of the day I wanted more of a horror movie, more of a crime movie.What we GOT was very good..... but I can't help but think it could have been better.This is not a proper concise review, I might be able to have one in the near future. Because like I said there's loads to get into.But I'll say I liked what I saw... but I need more time to process it.I'm definitely VERY curious to hear what others think of Joker.

Title: One of the greatest films I have ever seen
Review:
So i have seen it twice now with a heavy probability of going a few more if im being honest here.Its haunting, its brilliant, its tragic, its beautiful, its funny, its dark, its sad, its funny...its Joker.We have finally been blessed with every iteration of the joker their is. From the clown and the gangster, to the anarchist and the unhinged, but now we finally have the madman and the showman. Phoenix brought everything to this performance and with Phillips crafted a Joker thats elegant and chilling. Both times I have seen it I have walked away with more questions and more theories. But theres a grace in Phoenixs performance. A dance. He glides through these scenes
In a way i thought no actor would do with the joker. Its beautiful and painful and a pure expression of the soul. The bathroom scene alone...awestriking. (not a spoiler its in the trailer) Phoenix has done it folks. Ledger would be so proudI cant remember the last time i have seen a movie this good. Elements of the godfather, taxi driver, king of comedy, the killing joke, the dark knight/the dark knight returns, mark hamil, a clockwork orange, requiem for a dream, one flew over the cuckoos nest, psycho, silence of the lambs...the list goes on.The MUSIC and the cinematography are truly some of the best I had ever seen. You are left powerlessly mystified by Phoenix and Phillips dedication to the project.
Its a masterpiece in every sense of the word
Nothing in the last year or hell the last decade even TOUCHES how great this movie is...Its not for everybody thats for sure, its a stiff drink to swallow.I remember everybody being surprised when i said Endgame was not the comic book movie i was waiting for in 2019. I knew there was something special about this movie when i saw the screen test.
Never in my life would I think a movie like this would exist...but it does....and people are starting to notice...

Title: A beautiful, unique representation of a different type of Joker.
Review: I walked into the cinema with high hopes and I left completely fulfilled. I'm a massive Batman fan - both in comics, movies and television - and I was eager to see this latest iteration. I've enjoyed many portrayals of the Joker, from Nicholson to Ledger to Hamill. Each one showcases a different element of the Joker.Joaquin manages to present another side, whilst drawing from many aspects of the previous iterations. He plays on the mental side, showcasing a Joker developed out of circumstance. I feel Ledger's ambiguous Joker worked fantastically - which left you querying his reasons and mentality. This Joker is outright - you know his motivations and the film is a rollercoaster depicting that journey. He's a broken man with the weight of the world becoming overbearing - his fantasies so real that when they come crashing down with reality even I could sympathise with him.The art, setting and location were fantastic. Gotham felt real and dangerous, exactly as I'd picture a pre-Batman Gotham. The depiction of Thomas Wayne felt unique in that he was depicted more as a Trump-style capitalist rather than benevolent philanthropist although as his depiction is from the perspective of Arthur, it's possible he may not be as bad as depicted.I get the criticism based around the violence and how it utilises mental illness - it's very much topical and given recent and past events it was always going to dip into controversy. But I feel that it will be appreciated more once it settles. It is perhaps the "Killing Joke" of Joker movies.

Title: Marmite film
Review:
First review I've ever done on iMdB but I have to say this to everyone, this film is a marmite film; people will either love it or hate it.Many people will go in with the expectations of being on-par with The Dark Knight, but these two films are completely incomparable in their own right.The Dark Knight is a COMIC film, it involves all the action and all the pieces of comic stories put into an action masterpiece, and Heath Ledger's performance is extraordinary as the clown prince of crime.Joker is an extremely disturbing, dark yet invigorating film which shines the light less on the impact of Bruce Wayne and the Joker's battle with one another - it instead showcases an ill mans descent into madness, and shows how his past-experiences have effected him throughout his troubled life. Personally, I think if they moved away from some of the DC-orientated parts of the film it would've been better, but.. it is a film about THE JOKER.Overall I am absolutely amazed with Joaquin Phoenix's performance, it is truly Oscar-Winning and his portrayal consists mainly of the characters ill-nature rather than a complete psychopath.Should you go and see this film? YES.
But don't compare it to The Dark Knight, this film is not an action film, it is a gripping thriller and a dramatic masterpiece.

Title: FANTASTIC
Review:
Joker (2019) delivers a masterclass of acting by Joaquin Phoenix as Arthur Fleck and tells a deep and meaningful narrative in relation to society today. Joaquin Phoenix allows the audience to not only understand and empathise with the character 'Joker', but to also feel repulsed by some of the extreme actions he takes. When critics compare it to Heath Ledger, or downplay Joaquin Phoenix's character as an incel or angry white guy, they are sorely mistaken and most likely misunderstood the narrative of the film. Heath Ledger's Joker was a brilliant take on the character but you must understand that the 2019 Joker is introduced in a more psychologically engaging manner, where we are able to directly see Arthur's life before he became the joker. Whereas in the Dark Knight, the audience is only able to see the Joker post origin. If you think about it, the Dark Knight's joker has had many years to perfect his violent strategies, but Joaquin Phoenix's Joker is quite literally about the beginning of he Joker and what caused it.Put it simply, comparing the two Jokers would be unnecessary and irrelevant as they are focusing on the character in completely different parts of their lives.
No need to attack the film because it felt uncomfortable and real, this film was designed with that in mind and to make the audience think long and hard about the society they live in, including mental illness in contemporary society.

Title: Grey, gritty and nightmarish
Review:
Joaquin pheonix's JOKER is a gritty and nightmarish character study of Travis Bickle-esque "Arthur fleck" aka the JOKER who descends into madness for personally justifiable reasons.The film does draw inspirations from Martin Scorsese's TAXI DRIVER and THE KING of COMEDY but it's nothing like any of them. Its actually gives us a more deeper look at Travis bickle from TAXI DRIVER.Now, let's talk about the Joaquin Pheonix..of course I can't confine my admiration for him just to an IMDB review but anyway. Joaquin's performance is absolutely brilliant, menacing and terrorizing as the JOKER. He totally gives you the creeps. Having said this, although his portrayal of the character is brutally violent towards the finish, the intentional slow burn of the film gives you enough time to know him that you can't help but empathize with the character at least in some darkest corner of your mind.Who played it best: for this I'd say until Heath ledger terrified the world with his brilliant performance in the dark Knight we couldn't think of anybody else who could play it like jack nicholson and he undoubtedly superceded jack Nicholson's portrayal in the 1989 BATMAN.And now with JOKER Joaquin undoubtedly inherited the throne Heath left.üëèüëèüëèüëèüëè
Only if he were alive Heath would have lauded Joaquin's performance.thats how it works in any art form. There can be no ABSOLUTES what so ever. Ever body contributes to the medium.So i'd say kudos to Jack, Heath and JOAQUIN FREAKING PHEONIXTodd Philips I thank you so much for giving us such a great movie about the character we all love.I so so wish Matt Reeves considers Joaquin to play the joker in his upcoming Batman film if at all he plans to have a Joker in the film.Make way for GOTHAM'S new Clown Prince of Crime.

Title: A must read review for a must view film
Review:
I watched JOKER with superhero trepidation.As a stout Marvel fan and and having been somewhat let down by the promise that DC were going darker following Batman Begins and The Dark Knight (killings aside), I entered the theatre wondering what kind of picture Warner brothers would present.Some of the adverts prior to the movie were drol√© and tried to replicate the suggested horror and intrigue that would be presented in the film, but the copycats fell short of the truth.
Joker presents a dark and intrepid insight into the origins of one of DC's most fabled villains.
The acting by Phoenix was sublime and the setting held true to the history of the character and the references to the origins of batman were there to be seen.I do not want to dwell much on the story of the film as it would detract and deter some from witnessing this visual extravaganza and performance, and to surmise Joaquin Phoenix gives his soul to this homage and becomes truly encapsulating.
To bring this into modern context, it is a man who suffers from mental illness who loses his right to help from the government due to budget cuts whilst the over pompous capitalists drink champagne, ride in limo's and sleep in mansions whilst profiting from the lesser man. Much of this is only hinted at however and bares little influence to the piece as The Joker is not a political figure until he emerges from his metamorphis, which only occurs following a dramatic event - and this itself only happens near the end of the film.Phoenix depicts a truly delirious, deep, and troubled character haunted by the events of his family life which have echoed into his present and in some ways dictate his behavior's such as his memorable, yet haunting, uncontrollable laugh - which is well characterized in the movie.
There are a lot of comments regarding mental impairments and how this movie should have been a higher classification - but having looked at the BBFC category wording it neither dwells on any particular situation nor glorifies it - however it is a deep portrayal of a troubled and well know (sic) super villain and in the film there are at least 2 somewhat contentious moments so watch at your own {peril}.This film in my view, has been released at the most appropriate time. The world is waking up to the fact that fat cats (which include movie stars) are milking the lesser man (sic) as the societal gaps widens between rich and poor and this real life occurrence is well represented in this film.

Title: An astonishingly brilliant movie with a sledgehammer performance by Phoenix.
Review: Just saw this movie today in the cinema and my god what a hell of a film this is. Taking place in 1981, we are introduced to the origin of The Joker in all his dark, gritty, violent, psychotic glory. The transformation of Arthur Flecks character is ground breaking. we see this poor, misunderstood man mercilessly beaten multiple times before finally lashing out taking his first steps towards becoming this infamous villain we love so much getting deeper and progressively more intense and violent as the film goes on. There are a couple moments in this film that some might find hard to watch but it's seriously not as bad as what everyone's been saying about it. in saying that, this is definitely not a film for kids.Anyone who is familiar with the Batman films will know well and truly that Bruce Wayne's (Batman's) parents are murdered in front of him in an alley way when he's still only a young boy. This film shows this event and the events leading up to it. In terms of the overall timeline of events, Joker begins roughly 3 weeks before Bruce Wayne's parents are killed.Joker carries a very dark, stylish theme just like so many batman movies have done before it. the score, cinematography and the astonishing performance by Joaquin Phoenix are some of the biggest impacts a film has had on me over the last decade. We also have some strong political messages on display here too which I will not delve into here. Leave that for the forum sites =)Joker is one truly amazing film and is sure to go down as an all time masterpiece. 10 out of 10.

Title: A tragic masterpiece that will be talked about for many years to come!!!!!
Review: Where do I begin, the film follows Arthur Fleck, a man who is suffering from an uncontrollable mental affliction and occupies the lower echelons of society, through a series of events that lead him towards the path of becoming one of the most infamous villains in history: The Joker!!!!! All I have to say is this film is brilliant, disturbing, and of course tragic. Joaquin Phoenix brings an Oscar worthy performance throughout the whole movie as we follow his descent into madness. The soundtrack by Hildur Gudnadottir is a masterstroke, giving you this sense of sadness and horror as it plays throughout the film. Lawrence Sher's cinematography is absolutely stunning showcasing Arthur's world as ugly, fractured, yet strangely beautiful. And finally, the direction of Todd Phillips, along with his screenplay with Scott Silver, bring all of these elements together to portray a haunting tale of how a man with a fragile mindset can be turned into a monster by an unforgiving and corrupt society which won't be forgotten anytime soon.1 out of 1 found this helpful.Was this review helpful?Sign into vote.Permalink

It's a lie and an intentional misdirection to get clicks on their videos or news sites. It is completely not. So if you want to know why this movie is so drawn and quartered now in the US, it's because it sneaks in too much truth.So my recommendation is to go see it for yourselves. Title: Makes a great character study and executes a brilliant film.

It depicts a persons slip from sanity in a way that makes you go from fearing for him to those who oppose him. Not in a way the celebrates these vile acts he commits. It knows the tragedy of the character, and uses it to create a genuinely impactful character study and form a cationary tale around it.Though it was questioned rather comedy director Todd Phillips would be able to bring the chops needed for such a story. Such worries are moot, once the brutal grittyness, the nastyness the visaeral execution of these things play out. It's well as well, moving in a slow burn to bursts, akin to the characters own mind, before it snaps at the end.Carrying this all is Phaqin Penoix, who is meanicing, unnerving, yet with a dose of fun and sympathy. Title: A perfect ode to Heath Ledger
Review:
KNOCK KNOCK! Joker is one such exceptional film which gets the perfect balance of staying noir & elevating empathy for the protagonist.
The film delves with oppression, the oppressed from the first frame, and it becomes very evident, the journey of the protagonist will take a downward curve in the graph to bring out the change in the society, unfortunately resulting in anarchy.
The film never tries to pretend intelligent, and it plays well within the dramatics, not getting drifted away. There are some real beautiful scenes which brings out how oppressed the protagonist is and that too with his signature laugh, you feel for the character, you want to hoot for him to succeed, and you realise the actions by the protagonist to resolve the main conflict is not justified, and the filmmaker is careful not to glorify his actions rather smartly diverts us into the psyche of the protagonist as defense mechanism.
Joaquin Phoenix gives us a crackling performance, enacting the Joker himself, every scene- the laugh, the stare, the helplessness has been so consistent, that one would expect him to succeed for his dream of becoming a standup comedian and come out of this pity. This is a perfect ode to Heath Ledger, he would have been so happy to see this amazing performance by Joaquin Phoenix.
Lastly, the film beautifully portrays the real Joker on screen yet again, where his jokes are as subjective as his actions.
This film gives an urge to watch Heath Ledger's version of Joker.
Highly Recommended! Don't miss it!

Title: The Clown Prince of Crime is born!
Review: Yesterday, I went to watch the Joker, and I have to say that the film was absolutely brilliant. It has genuinely put a positive smile on my face! Joaquin Phoenix's performance, the overall storyline, along with how the film was put together is completely worth watching.As the Joker is a standalone film from the current list of DC films, it was refreshing to see a bold, dark and gritty attempt to deeply witness Arthur transform into one of the world's most notorious comic book villain. I would like to go in depth about his transition, but it is something the viewers need to watch for themselves. For me, this is one of the reasons why I enjoyed this film - it is not just about the Joker being a psychopath, but it is about understanding Arthur's circumstances, as well as his perspective about life.In terms of Joaquin Phoenix's portrayal of the Joker, I really enjoyed his take on the character, and his version is currently my favourite. The insanity and brutal stance (attitude) of Joaquin Phoenix's Joker is just mind-blowing, and this film gives us an opportunity to see an untamed and extreme Joker in a live action film.This film does contain some shocking, violent, along with gruesome scenes, and this is to be expected with a character like the Joker. He is not the clown you invite to your child's birthday party for an amusing experience. Looking back at the film, certain scenes were not even that horrific, and critics and individuals are unnecessarily attacking this film. There are other films and TV shows that are much more aggressive than the Joker.If you are yet to watch the film, go and see it without overthinking it. The hype that was within the trailers, expands throughout the film. It is that good. The Joker is a one of a kind film, and Todd Phillips has shown us what is possible for mature, in depth and dark comic book films.

Title: Spoiler Free review
Review:
Heath Ledger will probably always be my favorite rendition of The Joker, because of the charisma and intelligence he brought to the role.
With that said, I don't think anyone could have played this version of the Joker except for Joaquin Phoenix. He did things with the character, both through physicality of acting and through emotional depths, that both amazed and hurt me.
The movie is most definitely a drama and something of a personal journey of horror. It does not, as was my fear and the voiced concerns of many others, demonize everyone with a mental illness, or give justification for the incels and Red Pill Society members and MRA's to be terrible human beings. Neither does it say "Hey if you're alone and nobody likes you you can fix your problems with a little random violence." Instead, it shows us a plethora of factors, and a variety of nudges, that cause someone who's already struggling with who they are in life, and whether or not they actually even exist, to take a dark path. Joker shows us that those with mental illnesses, the 'clowns', the people considered broken or invisible or worthless by society as a whole, are being consistently let down by the system, at every turn. And Phoenix, and the writers, do an incredible job of showing us that The Joker is *human*. He's not some criminal mastermind, not at this point; he's very much figuring things out as he goes, and the film takes care to point out several times that the Joker is not making a political statement with his actions; he's not trying to enact sweeping change, or smash the Patriarchy, or fight The Man; he's just done with everyone's shit, and with how he feels the world is treating him. The movie doesn't have a lot of violence, but when it does it is brutal, harsh and quick; and it explores the ripple effects those violent acts cause.I found this to be an incredible film. I didn't come away from it feeling like it blamed those with mental issues or trauma; The Joker was very much responsible for his own actions, just as we all are. But it definitely helped remind me that underneath the makeup, there was still a human being in there, and it definitely made me analyze my feelings on the interactions between Batman and the Joker over the years.If you see this movie, expect to cry (I teared up several times) and to feel awkward; they do an excellent job of overextending an awkward situation until it becomes almost unbearable. Also, they somehow manage to be predictable without being boring; the predictability instead turns into a slow build of dread, because you can see where something is going a mile off, and then you're still along for the unavoidable end. And this movie is an R for a lot of language, and some fairly brutal violence.
It is not a movie that leaves you feeling good at the end, but it is one I am glad I went to see, and I hope that they tap Phoenix for the Joker in a future movie; he can clearly find that character's depths.

Title: Not just a great comic book movie, a great movie period!
Review: After Jared Leto's letdown performance as the character in 2016's Suicide Squad, Joaquin Phoenix delivers the best performance of The Joker since the late Heath Ledger in The Dark Knight!This film is a self contained story that doesn't draw heavily off of any one comic book story, though there are little nods to the comics, such as The Wayne Family/a young Bruce Wayne playing a prominent role in the movie, plus subtle nods to The Killing Joke and The Dark Knight Returns.It's in a dark, gritty world that the film takes place, as we are taken back to 1981 and we're transported to a Gotham City unlike any we've seen before on film, a city not unlike our real world. It's a Gotham City on the edge of chaos, and Phoenix's Arthur Fleck/Joker is the catalyst that throws the switch, as the people of Gotham begin to riot against the elite and upper class of the city and regard The Joker as a folk hero and Robin Hood type of figure. The film has major echoes of past 80s films, such as Taxi Driver and Dog Day Afternoon.It's within this gritty realism that the stakes of the movie takes place. Phoenix's portrayal of this mentally unstable man, whom society has turned it's back on, is both frightening and relatable. As his mental faculties begin to unravel, the viewer can't help but sympathize in some way with The Joker's plight. He's pained by what he's suffered in life, but he goes off the deep end into a life of crime. That's what makes Joaquin Phoenix's portrayal of the character so frightening. More than any other incarnation of the character, this one has echoes of our real world: that nothing is more frightening than a mentally unstable person with a gun.But it also leaves The Joker's backstory up in the air and up for debate by the end of the film, as Arthur/Joker is an unreliable narrator, and the audience is left wondering what exactly in the film's narrative was the truth and what were just delusions in The Joker's head.It's a film that transcends genres. It's not just a great comic book based film, it's a gritty, dark, and brilliantly done character study. It's a movie with real world consequences, as the characters are very reflective of the criminals that plague the news every day.An absolutely stunning performance by Joaquin Phoenix, and the movie definitely is worth every amount of acclaim it's getting! Phoenix deserves an Oscar! It's a brilliant piece of film!!

Title: Epic & Poetic
Review:
This movie is different. Different from average comic movies, adventures, dramas or thrillers.
It's not only a new perspective to the Joker, the world of Batman or DLC.
It's a music poet to in psychiatric illness, in sick society, in evil, in darkness of human soul.
A new way to make drama oe thriller movies.
A deep epic movie that leaves you with a scary laugh at the end, just like joker's.
